column1: The United States conducts its first underground n
column3: [html] The United States conducts its first underground nuclear test in the Nevada desert. [/html]

column1: Germany, Japan, and Italy officially become the Ax
column3: Germany, Japan, and Italy officially become the Axis powers when these countries sign the Tripartite pact in Berlin. The pact's primary goal is to discourage the United States from entering the war.

column1: 48 BC - Pompey the Great (Roman general and politi
column3: 48 BC - Pompey the Great (Roman general and politician) is assassinated on orders of his former ally after landing in Egypt to seek asylum. During his career Pompey led several victorious campaigns in Africa and Palestine, as well as defeating the gladiator army of Spartacus in Italy.

column1: Haratio Nelson, one of history's greatest naval co
column3: Haratio Nelson, one of history's greatest naval commanders, is born.  Nelson's greatest victory comes on October 21 1805, when he defeats a combined Franco-Spanish fleet near Trafalgar , Spain, denying Napoleon the ability to invade Britain. Wounded in the battle, he dies on HMS Victory . His last words were: Thank God, I have done my duty.

column1: The USS Nautilus (SSN-571), the world's first nucl
column3: The USS Nautilus (SSN-571), the world's first nuclear submarine, goes into service with the U.S. Navy. On one of its first big tests, the Nautilus covered 1381 miles in less than 90 hours . She remained submerged while en route, the longest submerged cruise to that date by a submarine, and at the highest sustained submerged speed ever recorded for a period of over one hour's duration. She was decommissioned on March 3, 1980 after a career spanning 25 years and almost half a million miles steamed.

column1: Napoleon is crowned emperor Napoleon I at Notre Da
column3: Napoleon is crowned emperor Napoleon I at Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris. He shortly begins the most successful campaigns of his career into Eastern Europe.

column1: General George S. Patton's troops arrive at the Si
column3: General George S. Patton's troops arrive at the Siegfried line (lines of defensive forts and tank defenses built by the Germans) situated on the border between France and Germany. He was planning to drive through to Czechoslovakia, but was interrupted a few weeks later when the German army launched their offensive in the Ardennes.

column1: Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitu
column3: Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified: Neither slavery nor involuntary servitude, except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted, shall exist within the United States, or any place subject to their jurisdiction.

column1: John Winston Ono Lennon was assassinated by a ment
column3: John Winston Ono Lennon was assassinated by a mentally deranged fan while returning home from a recording session.

column1: In North Africa British cryptographers were able t
column3: In North Africa British cryptographers were able to break the Italian military code, enabling British commanders to anticipate Italian troop movements, size, and points of vulnerability.  British command decided to make a first strike: 30,000 British soldiers launched an offensive against 80,000 Italians in North Africa, but the British brought with them 275 tanks against the Italians' 120. The British 7th Armored Division swept along the western coast to cut off any hope of an Italian retreat. Within three days, 40,000 Italian prisoners were taken. The end of the Italian occupation of North Africa had begun.

column1: Union General William T. Sherman completes his Mar
column3: Union General William T. Sherman completes his March to the Sea when he arrives in front of Savannah, Georgia during the US Civil War. The city of Savannah was fortified and defended by 10,000 Confederates under the command of General William Hardee. Union supply ships arrived to aid Sherman's troops which were running out of supplies. Hardee held out as Sherman prepared for an attack, but realizing the futility of losing in force entirely, Hardee fled the city on December 20.

column1: Confederate General Robert E. Lee's Army of Northe
column3: Confederate General Robert E. Lee's Army of Northern Virginia repulses a series of attacks by General Ambrose Burnside's Army of the Potomac at Fredericksburg, Virginia. The defeat was one of the most decisive losses for the Union army. The campaign began promisingly for the Union. The army moved quickly down the Rappahannock, but then stalled when a pontoon bridge was not in place for several days. The delay allowed Lee to move his troops into a sunken road protected by a stone wall, looking down on the open slopes that stretched from the edge of Fredericksburg. So strong was the Confederate position that one Rebel officer claimed that a chicken could not live on that field when we open on it.  Unfortunately for the Union, Burnside decided to attack anyway. On December 13,  Burnside hurled 14 attacks against the Confederate lines. Although the Union artillery was effective against the Rebels, the six-hundred yard field was a killing ground for the attacking Yankees. No Union soldiers reached the wall at the top of Marye's Heights, and few even came within fifty yards of it.

column1: USS Swordfish becomes 1st US sub to sink a Japanes
column3: USS Swordfish becomes 1st US sub to sink a Japanese ship and on the same day...German submarine U-127 sunk west of Gibraltar by depth charges from the Australian destroyer HMAS Nestor: all hands (51) lost.

column1: Battle of the Bulge begins: Hitler ordered a massi
column3: Battle of the Bulge begins: Hitler ordered a massive attack against the western Allies by three German armies.  The German counterattack out of the densely wooded Ardennes region of Belgium took the Allies entirely by surprise, and the experienced German troops wrought havoc on the American line, creating a triangular bulge 60 miles deep and 50 miles wide along the Allied front. Until a three-point counteroffensive led by British General Bernard Montgomery and Americans generals Omar Bradley and George Patton.

column1: During the Battle of the Bulge, the German command
column3: During the Battle of the Bulge, the German commander besieging the town of Bastogne demanded that the Americans surrender or face annihilation. U.S. Major General Anthony McAuliffe prepared a typed reply that read simply:To the German Commander:Nuts! From the American Commander [There's a pretty good Nuts museum in Bastogne, if you're ever nearby]

column1: Orville Wright took to the air. Orville's controll
column3: Orville Wright took to the air. Orville's controlled flight, of 36 meters (120 feet) in 12 seconds, was recorded in a famous photograph. In the fourth flight of the same day, the only flight made that day which was actually controlled, Wilbur Wright flew 259 meters (852 feet) in 59 seconds.

column1: Adolf Hitler issues his secret plans for the invas
column3: Adolf Hitler issues his secret plans for the invasion of the Soviet Union--Operation Barbarossa.

column1: Defended by 610 fighting men, the American-held is
column3: Defended by 610 fighting men, the American-held island of Guam falls to more than 5,000 Japanese invaders in a three-hour battle.

column1: General George S. Patton, commander of the U.S. 3r
column3: General George S. Patton, commander of the U.S. 3rd Army, dies from injuries suffered not in battle but in a freak car accident. - Patton graduated from the West Point Military Academy in 1909 - He represented the United States in the 1912 Olympics-as the first American participant in the pentathlon - he did not win a medal- Commanded the US Tank Corps during World War I and received a Purple Heart, a Distinguished Service Cross and was given a battlefield promotion to a full colonel after being wounded by machine gun fire as he sought assistance for tanks that were mired in the mud in the St. Mihiel offensive - Commander of the U.S. 7th Army, that captured Palermo, Sicily, in 1943 - In August of 1943 while visiting hospitals and commending wounded soldiers, he slapped and verbally abused 2 soldiers who were suffering from shell-shock and had no visible wounds because he thought were exhibiting cowardly behavior - Patton was relieved of command of the Seventh Army - During the Battle of the Bulge, he employed an unorthodox strategy that involved a 90-degree pivoting move of his 3rd Army forces, enabling him to speedily relieve the besieged Allied defenders of Bastogne, Belgium - AS

column1: Born Today: Arnold Ludwig Mendelssohn (composer),
column3: Born Today: Arnold Ludwig Mendelssohn (composer), Charles Babbage (inventor - calculating machine), Mao Tse-tung (Chinese PM), Lars Ulrich (Metallica)

column1: Having advanced as far as the Myshkova river 30 mi
column3: Having advanced as far as the Myshkova river 30 miles southwest of Stalingrad, the three Panzer divisions of the relief force have exhausted their power and begin to withdraw towards their starting line at Kotelnikovo.

column1: The United States and United Kingdom signed the Tr
column3: The United States and United Kingdom signed the Treaty of Ghent, ending the War of 1812. Despite the signing of the treaty, the war continued for several weeks, including the Battle of New Orleans as the news of the treaty took time to reach all of North America.

column1: The Vergeltungswaffe 1 FZG-76 (V1), known as the B
column3: The Vergeltungswaffe 1 FZG-76 (V1), known as the Buzz Bomb was the first modern guided missile used in wartime. Because of the buzzing sound of the engine, it caused considerable fear in targeted areas. If the engine noise cut out, it was time to duck, as the missile would then go into its terminal dive.

column1: Born Today: Jesus of Nazareth
column3: Born Today: Jesus of Nazareth

column1: Heavy fighting continues all around the perimeter
column3: Heavy fighting continues all around the perimeter of Stalingrad, while the decimated and starving troops of 6th Army receive their last rations of horse meat, the 12,000 horses in the pocket having now all been slaughtered

column1: The Battle of Trenton took place during the Americ
column3: The Battle of Trenton took place during the American Revolutionary War. George Washington led the main Continental Army across the Delaware to surprise and virtually eliminate the Hessian garrison at Trenton, New Jersey.

column1: Soviet troops invade Afghanistan. With air support
column3: Soviet troops invade Afghanistan. With air support, logistics, MVD troops, and other miscellaneous troops, the total number is estimated by some observers at approximately 175,000 troops total. The Soviet forces eventually left the country by February of 1989.

column1: Stalin, suspicious of their loyalty due to their d
column3: Stalin, suspicious of their loyalty due to their dissatisfaction with their conditions, deported the whole Kalmyk nation (the only Buddhist state in Europe) without notice to Siberia in cattle trucks. Half of their 140,000 number perished during the journey and in the following years of exile.

column1: The 7th Cavalry under Colonel James Forsyth surrou
column3: The 7th Cavalry under Colonel James Forsyth surrounded a band of Ghost Dancers (an Indian spiritual movement) under the Sioux Chief Big Foot near Wounded Knee Creek and demanded they surrender their weapons. Big Foot and his followers agreed to surrender and began turning over their guns. As that was happening, a scuffle broke out between an Indian and a soldier, and a shot was fired. Though no one is certain which side fired it, the ensuing melee was quick and brutal. Without arms and outnumbered, the Sioux were reduced to hand-to-hand fighting with knives, and they were cut down in a withering rain of bullets, many coming from the army's rapid-fire repeating Hotchkiss guns. By the time the soldiers withdrew, 146 Indians were dead (including 44 women and 18 children) and 51 wounded. The 7th Cavalry had 25 dead and 39 wounded.  Although sometimes referred to as a battle, the conflict at Wounded Knee is best seen as a tragic and avoidable massacre.

column1: The U.S.S. Monitor sinks in a storm off Cape Hatte
column3: The U.S.S. Monitor sinks in a storm off Cape Hatteras, North Carolina. Just nine months earlier, the ship had been part of a revolution in naval warfare when the ironclad dueled to a standstill with the C.S.S. Virginia (Merrimack) off Hampton Roads, Virginia, in one of the most famous naval battles in history--the first time two ironclads faced each other in a naval engagement.

column1: The provisional government of Hungary officially d
column3: The provisional government of Hungary officially declares war on Germany, bringing an end to Hungary's cooperation - sometimes free, sometimes coerced - with the Axis power. When the Germans invaded the Soviet Union, Hitler demanded that Hungary mobilize its military against the Soviets as well. So, Hungary declared war on the USSR. As Soviet troops began to occupy more Hungarian territory, a desperate regent signed an armistice with Moscow, but when it was announced on radio, he was kidnapped by the Germans and forced to abdicate. Soviet troops finally liberated the bulk of Hungary from German rule in December 1944.

column1: The British battleship Formidable was hit by a U-b
column3: The British battleship Formidable was hit by a U-boat's torpedo and lost more than 500 men - who were retrieved from the English Channel and stacked on the floor of a pub in Lyme Regis, England. The pub's half-collie, when she was called away, refused to leave the bodies and began to lick the face of one of the victims. Nuzzling his head and body, she stayed with him for more than 30 minutes, whereupon he showed signs of life, was rushed to a hospital and eventually made a full recovery. [The dog's name was Lassie and inspired the bestseller Lassie Come Home]

column1: U.S. Air Force F-4 Phantom jets down seven communi
column3: U.S. Air Force F-4 Phantom jets down seven communist MiG-21s over North Vietnam. The Phantoms were flying cover for F-105 Thunderchief fighter-bombers, which were attacking surface-to-air missile sites in the Red River Delta. During this operation, Col. Robin Olds shot down one of the MiGs, becoming the first and only U.S. Air Force ace with victories in both World War II and Vietnam.

column1: Lt. Gen. Charles Cornwallis declares We'll bag the
column3: Lt. Gen. Charles Cornwallis declares We'll bag the fox in the morning,  not realizing that Maj. Gen. George Washington has left behind a few men, bonfires, and wooden cannons as decoys in his previous position. Meanwhile, Washington's army launched the Battle of Princeton and defeated the British force left behind by Cornwallis.

column1: U.S. aircraft begin dropping supplies to guerrilla
column3: U.S. aircraft begin dropping supplies to guerrilla forces throughout Western Europe. Virtually every country that experienced Axis invasion raised a guerrilla force

column1: Twenty eight BW B-29 Superfortress bombers dispatc
column3: Twenty eight BW B-29 Superfortress bombers dispatched from Chengtu, China, attack an aircraft factory and urban areas at Omura with 91 tons of bombs. Thirteen bomb a secondary target at Nanking, China while 6 attack targets of opportunity. One B-29 (Rushorder, with crew of 12) is lost after losing 2 of their 4 engines to Japanese fighters. This is the last mission against targets in Japan from the base which is abandoned after the mission.

column1: Field Marshal Bernard Montgomery, 1st Viscount Mon
column3: Field Marshal Bernard Montgomery, 1st Viscount Montgomery of Alamein held a press conference in which he claimed credit for the victory in the Battle of the Bulge. Prime Minister Winston Churchill later announced that the battle was an American operation and was won by Americans. American losses in the battle were over 75,500 while British losses were only 1408.

column1: In The Battle of New Orleans, Major General Sir Ed
column3: In The Battle of New Orleans, Major General Sir Edward Pakenham's force of 10,000 was defeated by General Andrew Jackson's 5,000 fortified troops. British losses were 2036, American losses were 71. Neither side knew that the war had officially ended two weeks prior.

column1: Fullfulling his 2/22/42 promise of I shall return,
column3: Fullfulling his 2/22/42 promise of I shall return, General Douglas MacArthur and the American 6th Army land on the Lingayen Gulf of Luzon, another step in the capture of the Philippine Islands from the Japanese.

column1: Born Today: Aleksei Tolstoi (Russian writer), Geor
column3: Born Today: Aleksei Tolstoi (Russian writer), George Foreman (Boxer), Pat Benatar (Singer)

column1: Gaius Julius Caesar crossed the Rubicon river (Rom
column3: Gaius Julius Caesar crossed the Rubicon river (Roman law forbade any general from crossing it with a standing army) and started a civil war. Caesar had been ordered to return to Rome and disband his army, but he knew that he would be prosecuted and politically eliminated if he entered Rome. [That year should be 49 BC, but not allowed - AS]

column1: Soviet troops create a breach in the German siege
column3: Soviet troops create a breach in the German siege of Leningrad and allowed for more supplies to come in along Lake Ladoga. Upon invading the Soviet Union in June 1941, German troops made a beeline for Leningrad, the second-largest city in the USSR. In August, German forces, approaching from the west and south, surrounded the city and rendered the Leningrad-Moscow railway useless. A German offensive attempted to occupy the city but failed

column1: The Red Army opens an offensive in South Poland, c
column3: The Red Army opens an offensive in South Poland, crashing 25 miles through the German lines. Germany and the Soviet Union agreed to split Poland at the begining of the war with the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact. Poland lost a larger percent of its population during the war than any other nation.

column1: On the USS Enterprise (CVN-65), the world's first
column3: On the USS Enterprise (CVN-65), the world's first nuclear aircraft carrier, an accidental armament explosion on a below deck aircraft sparked a large fire and further explosions of munitions or fuel while 70 nm from Honolulu, Hawaii. Twenty-eight crew were killed and over 150 were wounded. The CVN-65 is the eighth naval vessel to be called the USS Enterprise  - that does not include the Starship Enterprise :)

column1: The USS Hatteras, an 1126-ton side-wheel steamer w
column3: The USS Hatteras, an 1126-ton side-wheel steamer with 4 x 32 pound cannons and 1 x 20 pounder, encountered the Confederate commerce raider CSS Alabama with 6 x 32-pound cannons, 1 x 110 pounder, and 1 x 68 pounder, flying the British flag (an acceptable practice under the law of the sea at the time) and indicating that she was the HMS Spitfire. As a boarding party approached the Alabama she broke out the Confederate ensign and commenced firing. A fierce 40-minute battle ensued until the Hatteras was overpowered and began to sink.

column1: Allied forces broke through the fortified Winter L
column3: Allied forces broke through the fortified Winter Line (in its sector as the Gustav Line) spanning the Italian peninsula along the Sangro and Garigliano rivers. The 5th Army seized Mounts Camino and San Pietro, crossed the Garigliano and reached and crossed the Rapido river below Monte Cassino. The formidable defensive position of Monte Cassino wasn't taken until almost 18 months later.

column1: One day after the deadline set in Resolution 678,
column3: One day after the deadline set in Resolution 678, Persian Gulf War #1 (codenamed Operation Desert Storm) begins as an air campaign that is made up of more than 1,000 sorties per day. Five weeks later a ground campaign started that took 3 days to get Iraqi troops to exit Kuwait.

column1: Nazi personnel started to evacuate Auschwitz
column3: Nazi personnel started to evacuate Auschwitz

column1: The Germans counter attack in Tunisia. They gain g
column3: The Germans counter attack in Tunisia. They gain ground against the Free French, but are repulsed by British forces. This date sees the first use in the Africa campaign of the Panzerkampfwagen VI Ausführung H, or the Tiger as it was nicknamed by Ferdinand Porsche. The Tiger could destroy most opponents from 1600 m. The Soviet T-34 could only penetrate the Tiger from 1000 m. The M4 Sherman could only penetrate the Tiger from 500 m. and from the side. (sorry, no data on the Churchill) The Tiger dominated action at first until it's slow speed, massive weight, and common mechanical problems limited the number in use.

column1: General Wavell warns Churchill that Singapore cann
column3: General Wavell warns Churchill that Singapore cannot be held as little had been done to prepare the landward facing defences. Churchill replies that Singapore must be defended and that 'no question of surrender be entertained until after protracted fighting among the ruins of Singapore city'. General Wavell orders General Percival to prepare Singapore Island for a siege. Japanese troop capture Tavoy as their advance continues in Burma.

column1: The Japanese 55th Division crosses the Thai-Burmes
column3: The Japanese 55th Division crosses the Thai-Burmese border from Raheng. They quickly threaten Moulmein in Burma, using the same tactics as in Malaya of outflanking British forces through the Jungle.

column1: Without consulting higher authority, Rommel launch
column3: Without consulting higher authority, Rommel launches a counter-offensive against the 8th Army. The 21st Panzer Division quickly seizes Mersa Brega, while the 15th Panzer Division advances to Wadi Faregh and swings north towards Agedabia, brushing aside the attempts by the 1st Armoured Division to stop them.

column1: Tobruk surrenders to British and Australian troops
column3: Tobruk surrenders to British and Australian troops who capture 25,000 Italians, along with 208 guns and 87 tanks. Combined British and Australian losses were about 450. The British government now orders Wavells XIII Corps to capture Benghazi.

column1: Four US destroyers and several submarines attack a
column3: Four US destroyers and several submarines attack a Japanese convoy in the Macassar Strait between Borneo and Celebes, sinking 1 destroyer and four transports, while only suffering damage to one of their destroyers. This action delays the impending Japanese invasion of Java.

column1: “We were carrying out a bombing mission on Magdebu
column3: “We were carrying out a bombing mission on Magdeburg. Our aircraft was attacked twice by a night fighter, setting us ablaze on the first attack. My earphones were put out of commission so I did not hear the order to bail out. I know that I owe my life to the fact that I was blown out of the aircraft. I know Al was preparing to jump. Al and I had been good pals all the way and used to go out a great deal together, I can sympathize with you on the loss of your brother-my-friend. He had been a conscientious member of our crew and so full of life that it doesn’t seem fair that he had to make the sacrifice.” Earl James Clare’s Lancaster was shot down by Major Prinz Heinrich zu Sayn Wittgenstein, at the time the Luftwaffe’s top scoring night fighter who claimed 83 victories. Wittgenstein’s JU 88 also crashed and he was killed.

column1: Japanese troops land at Rabaul on New Britain, Kav
column3: Japanese troops land at Rabaul on New Britain, Kavieng on New Ireland, Bougainville Island in the Solomons, and Kendari in Celebes. Australia appeals to Britain and the US for immediate reinforcements.

column1: The US-Filipino withdrawal to the Bagac-Orion line
column3: The US-Filipino withdrawal to the Bagac-Orion line is successfully completed. The Japanese quickly followed up the withdrawal and made several penetrations into the new defensive line, although these were all contained and thrown back.

column1: Soviet troops liberate the 3000 remaining prisoner
column3: Soviet troops liberate the 3000 remaining prisoners of Auschwitz. By this time, an estimated 2,000,000 persons, including 1,500,000 Jews, have been murdered there.

column1: The whole of the German workforce is mobilised for
column3: The whole of the German workforce is mobilised for ‘total war’. All men aged 16-65 and women aged 17- 50 to be registered

column1: The allied thrust into the Rhineland continues wit
column3: The allied thrust into the Rhineland continues with the capture of Oberhausen, 10 miles Northeast of Duisberg. Quisling meets Hitler in Berlin for the last time.

column1: Born Today: Daniel Bernoulli (Mathematician), W C
column3: Born Today: Daniel Bernoulli (Mathematician), W C Fields (Actor), Tommy Ramone (Rocker), Heather Graham (Actress)

column1: With the German Sixth Army in its death throes at
column3: With the German Sixth Army in its death throes at Stalingrad, Hitler does the seemingly unthinkable and allows the 10th anniversary of the Nazi seizure of power to pass without speaking to the nation. It is the first unmistakable evidence of Hitler's retreat from public appearances as the tide of the war turns.

column1: British and Commonwealth forces complete their eva
column3: British and Commonwealth forces complete their evacuation of Malaya and withdraw to Singapore Island across the causeway with the Japanese only 8 miles away. Singapore now has the equivalent of four divisions to defend it, but morale is low and there are serious shortages of weapons. An additional Indian Brigade is landed at Rangoon and sent to join the 17th Indian Division.

column1: All U-boats adopt a new Enigma cipher known as 'Tr
column3: All U-boats adopt a new Enigma cipher known as 'Triton'. The new cipher replaces the previous cipher, 'Hydra' and has an additional rotor in the Enigma machine. This meant that the British were unable to read U-boat coded communications traffic until much later in the year, seriously affecting their ability re-route their convoys around U-boat wolf packs.

column1: Born Today: Brig. Gen. Abner Perrin (Confederate A
column3: Born Today: Brig. Gen. Abner Perrin (Confederate Army), James Joyce (Novelist), Farrah Fawcett (Actress), Brent Spiner (Star Trek's Data)

column1: The remnants of the German 6th Army under General
column3: The remnants of the German 6th Army under General Strecker in the northern pocket cease fighting and surrender to the Red Army. In all, over 96,000 survivors of the once 300,000-strong Army are captured, of which, only about 5,000 will live to return to Germany after the war. At Moscow, the victory over the Germans is celebrated with a salute of several hundred guns.

column1: President Quezon of the Philippines proposes to Pr
column3: President Quezon of the Philippines proposes to President Roosevelt that his country should be granted total independence from the USA so that it could declare itself neutral, but Roosevelt dismisses this idea. General MacArthur warns Roosevelt that the Bataan garrison has suffered over 50 per cent casualties and it was 'near done'. MacArthur was given permission by Roosevelt to surrender Filipino, but not US troops who were to fight until the end.

column1: US forces take Kwajalein Island in Marshall's, los
column3: US forces take Kwajalein Island in Marshall's, losing 486 killed and 1,495 wounded, but inflicting 8,386 casualties on the Japanese.

column1: Dutch collaborator, General Seyffardt, was assassi
column3: Dutch collaborator, General Seyffardt, was assassinated by the Dutch resistance movement. In response, 250 hostages were shot by the Germans.

column1: Australian forces capture Benghazi along with six
column3: Australian forces capture Benghazi along with six senior Italian Generals. Italian forces make repeated attempts to break through the weak British blocking forces at Beda Fomm, but cannot. Lieutenant General Erwin Rommel is appointed to command the German forces being sent to Africa.

column1: After just over 2 weeks of frenetic action, Rommel
column3: After just over 2 weeks of frenetic action, Rommel's counter-offensive comes to a halt in front of the Gazala line, a series of self supporting fortified boxes running south from Gazala for a 100 miles to Bir Hacheim. Although not complete, it presents too much of an obstacle for the Afrika Korps who by this time are running low on fuel and reserves.

column1: Britain declared a formal cessation of hostilities
column3: Britain declared a formal cessation of hostilities with its former colonies, the United States of America..

column1: RAF Balloon Command to be disbanded as the air rai
column3: RAF Balloon Command to be disbanded as the air raid threat lessens. 278 V1s have been claimed by balloons.

column1: The RAF uses a massive 12,000b bomb ‘Tall-Boy’, in
column3: The RAF uses a massive 12,000b bomb ‘Tall-Boy’, in a raid on the Gnôme-et-Rhône works in Limoges, the second biggest bomb used in WWII. The Tall-Boy reached the speed of sound during descent being streamlined and equipped with angled fins that produced a rapid spin. Penetrating the ground before exploding they worked by setting off shock waves that would bring down nearby structures. The 5,443 kg (12,000 lb) Tall Boy dropped from 6,096m (20,000 feet) made a 24 meter (80 feet) deep crater 30 meter (100 feet) across and could go through 4.88 meter 16 feet of concrete.

column1: The Confederate States of America is formed with J
column3: The Confederate States of America is formed with Jefferson Davis as president.

column1: British and Canadians troops smash the first of th
column3: British and Canadians troops smash the first of the main Siegfried Lines defense zone. The last Rhine bridge is blown in the Colmar Pocket. Half the German Nineteenth Army were evacuated, but General De Lattre's forces have taken 22,000 German prisoners since January 20th.

column1: The RAF attacks the oil storage tanks at Rotterdam
column3: The RAF attacks the oil storage tanks at Rotterdam in the Netherlands. The raid sees the operational debut of the RAF's first 4-engine heavy bomber, the Stirling.

column1: Americans troops at Monte Cassino are relieved by
column3: Americans troops at Monte Cassino are relieved by Indian and New Zealand forces. The allies are pushed back to a final defensive line at Anzio. Monte Cassino is a rocky hill about eighty miles south of Rome, IT. This is the Second Battle for Monte Cassino

column1: Born Today: Abraham Lincoln (US president), Charle
column3: Born Today: Abraham Lincoln (US president), Charles Darwin (Biologist), Christina Ricci (Actress)

column1: In North Africa, the Italians make further breakou
column3: In North Africa, the Italians make further breakout attempts, which all fail. Later in the day the Italians surrender 20,000 men, 200 guns and 120 tanks to just 3,000 British troops. Anthony Eden makes a speech parodying Winston Churchill's famous 'Battle of Britain' speech. He says Never has so much been surrendered, by so many, to so few.  Lieutenant General Rommel arrives in Tripoli and reports to General Gariboldi who has replaced Marshal Graziani as commander of the Italian Army in Libya.

column1: Even though the war is almost over, and the city d
column3: Even though the war is almost over, and the city did not hold any military significance, the allies begin the bombing of Dresden. Dresden is the capital city of the German federal state of Saxony, and suffered losses estimated between 30,000 and 125,000.

column1: Bomber Command is issued with Directive No.22, whi
column3: Bomber Command is issued with Directive No.22, which ends the recent period of aircraft conservation by the RAF, although attacks are still not to be pressed in the face of bad weather or 'extreme hazard'. The reason for this change is that the new Lancaster bomber, was just entering service and that Bomber Command was now equipped with a new navigation device called GEE, which it was hoped would make locating targets easier. However, it only had a range of 400 miles and could be jammed.

column1: German operation Sonnenwende (Solstice) was launch
column3: German operation Sonnenwende (Solstice) was launched into the remnants of the Soviet operation Vistula-Oder. Gen. Wenck's King Tiger tanks were destroying large amounts of Soviet tanks at long range, showing their supremacy at such distance. But, while the Germans had to regroup and wait for fuel and ammo, the Soviets pushed forward. They split the Panzer Army and captured the tanks and AFVs that the Germans had to leave behind because they were out of fuel.

column1: Born Today: Johann Strauss (Composer),  Sonny Bono
column3: Born Today: Johann Strauss (Composer),  Sonny Bono (Singer), Ice-T (Singer/actor), John McEnroe (Tennis player), Matt Groening (Simpson's creator)

column1: The British destroyer Cossack, enters a Norwegian
column3: The British destroyer Cossack, enters a Norwegian fjord, captures the German freighter Altmark, former supply ship of the Graf Spee and frees 300 British merchant seamen who were captured from vessels sunk by the Graf Spee in the South Atlantic.  Both sides were in violation of international law

column1: German forces continue attacks on the Anzio beachh
column3: German forces continue attacks on the Anzio beachhead. The US 45th Division barely contains the German attack. Heavy losses are sustained by both sides. Offshore, the British cruiser Penelope is damaged by a torpedo attack. To the south, near Cassino, German forces recover Point 593 after losing possession briefly to the British 4th Indian Division (part of the US 5th Army).

column1: A Russian torpedo hits the Wilhelm Gustloff a conv
column3: A Russian torpedo hits the Wilhelm Gustloff a converted Nazi cruise liner leaving Danzig for Denmark with 5,000 refugees and 3,800 U-boat personnel on board. Only 1,000 are reported as saved, making it the worst maritime disaster. By comparison, the Titanic disaster lost only 1,523 lives.

column1: US Marines divisions land on Iwo Jima. In the Paci
column3: US Marines divisions land on Iwo Jima. In the Pacific Iwo Jima is strategically and politically significant to both sides. The Americans need the island as a fighter base (Mustangs P-51 fighters) for their Japanese raids (B-29's) and a relief base for damaged bombers. On the first day some 30.000 marines landed, the about 23.000 Japanese soldiers have prepared defences but allow the landing to take place before opening fire. Over the next two months 6.281 US soldiers are killed (in the first 2 days, 4000 US soldiers died), and 21.865 are wounded in capturing the island from 23.000 defenders, 21.000 Japanese soldiers died.

column1: Lt. EH O'Hare flying from the carrier Lexington in
column3: Lt. EH O'Hare flying from the carrier Lexington in a Wildcat, single-handedly shoots down 5 Japanese heavy bombers that had been sent to attack the Lexington. O'Hare was promoted to Lieutenant Commander and awarded the highest decoration of his country, the Congressional Medal of Honor. His home town of Chicago named their airport after him - O'Hare International.

column1: Convoy ON-166 (60 ships) sailing from Britain to N
column3: Convoy ON-166 (60 ships) sailing from Britain to North America, is attacked in the North Atlantic by 19 U-boats from wolfpacks Ritter and Knappen between the 21st and 26th February. 14 allied ships are lost for 87,901 tons. 4 U-boats U-225, U-606, U-529, U623 were sunk during the battle.

column1: The 1st Destroyer Flottilla comprised of the Fried
column3: The 1st Destroyer Flottilla comprised of the Friedrich Eckoldt and five other destroyers were dispatched to intercept suspicious  civilian ship activity. An aircraft approached the Flotilla and made several passes.  Thinking it was a British reconnaissance aircraft, the Erich Koellner fired several 20 mm rounds at the plane. Several bombs struck the Leberecht Maas, breaking it in two. Chaos ensued as multiple torpedoes  and periscopes were observed in the minutes following.  All survivors in a life boat tethered to the Erich Koellner were lost as the destroyer accelerated to full-speed, capsizing the tiny craft. The enemy plane that sunk the two destroyers was actually a Luftwaffe He111 bomber.  There was no enemy submarine.

column1: Born Today: George Frideric Händel (composer),  Jo
column3: Born Today: George Frideric Händel (composer),  Johnny Winter (giutarist), Ed Too Tall Jones (NFL player)

column1: US 1st Paratrooper Battalion rescue 2,146 detainee
column3: US 1st Paratrooper Battalion rescue 2,146 detainees from a Japanese internment camp (former University of the Philippines Agricultural School) 25 miles behind enemy lines. The camp on the shores of Laguna de Bay, the large interior lake SE of Manila. During the operation 243 Japanese are killed for loss of just two U.S. killed and two injured.

column1: The Zimmerman Telegram is delivered to US Presiden
column3: The Zimmerman Telegram is delivered to US President Wilson. The telegram from German Foreign Minister Arthur Zimmerman asked Mexico to reconquer the lost territory in New Mexico, Texas, and Arizona, and so distract the US away from WWI. Release of the letter to the public (by British intelligence) helped sway public opinion away from Germany.

column1: The USS Ranger , the first US warship designed and
column3: The USS Ranger , the first US warship designed and built as an aircraft carrier, was launched. The Ranger served in the Atlantic from 1941-1944, participated in the North African invasion, and the October, 1943 raid on Norway. Used as a training ship from 1944 to the end of the war, and was decomissioned in 1946.

column1: U-35, commanded by Lothar von Arnauld de la Perièr
column3: U-35, commanded by Lothar von Arnauld de la Perière, sinks the French transport ship Provence II, killing 930. U-35 was one of Germany's most successful u-boats: in 4 years and 8 days of operation it was responsible for sinking 224 ships.

column1: The Battle of the Java Sea begins and continues fo
column3: The Battle of the Java Sea begins and continues for three days, during which the Allies, under the command of the Dutch Admiral, Karel Doorman lose five cruisers and six destroyers, while the Japanese lose just 4 transports. The USS Houston, the largest US warship in SE Asia is sunk by gunfire and torpedoes from cruisers Mogami and Mikuma.

column1: Norsk Hydro 'heavy water' plant raid. Operation Gu
column3: Norsk Hydro 'heavy water' plant raid. Operation Gunnerside was carried out by Norwegian resistance soldiers trained in the UK and dropped by the RAF. They inflicted damage to the 'heavy water' plant at the Norsk Hydro power station near Ryukan. While the American atomic homb was being developed, it was feared that the Gemans were conducting parallel research since it was a German scientist who had discovered atomic fission and Germans had first published the theory of the chain-reacting pile. But the early purging from universities of suspected intellectuals and Jews had seriously weakened the German research teams.

column1: The heavy cruiser USS Houston and light cruiser HM
column3: The heavy cruiser USS Houston and light cruiser HMAS Perth, along with 1 British, 1 Dutch and 2 US destroyers, fleeing from the debacle at the Battle of Java Sea, surprise a Japanese landing force at Bantam Bay near the Sundra Strait, and are sunk by torpedoes and gunfire.  The Japanese force, comprising 2 heavy cruisers, one light cruiser, 9 destroyers, and various transports, manage to sink a minesweeper and a transport of their own, and seriously damage 3 more transports, through the unprecedented firing of 87 torpedoes. The rescued USS Houston crew were the first prisoners of World War II to be taken by the Japanese. Many of them were transported to Burma where they were forced to build the Burma-Thai Railway. The most famous bridge of the railroad came to be known as the Bridge over the River Kwai.

column1: The Battle of the Bismarck Sea opens Northeast of
column3: The Battle of the Bismarck Sea opens Northeast of New Guinea. A Japanese convoy is attacked by USAF B25 bombers, which sink 12 ships. The USAF had been experimenting with a new aerial tactic called skip-bombing, wherein the attacking airplane drops a bomb with a long-delay fuze close to the surface and lets it skip into the side of the target ship. This was the first occasion in which the Americans would use this new tactic. Of the nearly 4000 Japanese troops heading for New Guinea, only 850 were not lost.

column1: RAF Bomber Command, under its new C-in-C, Air Vice
column3: RAF Bomber Command, under its new C-in-C, Air Vice Marshal Harris, attacks the Renault plant in the Paris suburb of Billancourt. Of the 235 RAF planes that took off, only 1 failed to return. The target was marked with flares for the first time and serious damage done to production facilities, although many French workers were killed. On this same night, the Lancaster bomber makes its operational debut, laying mines of the French port of Brest.

column1: The Boston Massacre occurs when a young apprentice
column3: The Boston Massacre occurs when a young apprentice named Edward Gerrish accosted a British officer on the night of March 5 in King Street for a payment due his master. When he became vocal, a British sentry, Private White left his post outside the customs house to club the boy. Gerrish returned soon after with a group of boys who pelted White with snow, ice, and trash. The commotion brought the Officer of the Day, Captain Thomas Preston, who came to the soldier's aid with a corporal and eight other soldiers. The mob grew in size and continued throwing things at the British soldiers. As the parties closed, the soldiers fired. In this action, five Americans died, becoming the first-known casualties of the American Revolution.

column1: Convoy RA-57 (31 ships) sailing the Arctic route f
column3: Convoy RA-57 (31 ships) sailing the Arctic route from the Kola Peninsula to Loch Ewe, is attacked off Norway. The steam merchant Empire Tourist is sunk by U-703 for 7,062 gross tons lost. However, the convoys escorts sink 3 U-boats en-route, including U-472 which is sunk by gunfire and rockets from the British destroyer HMS Onslaught and Swordfish aircraft of the escort carrier HMS Chaser. HMS Chaser chasing pic

column1: Remember the Alamo After a 13-day siege (waiting f
column3: Remember the Alamo After a 13-day siege (waiting for their 12lb cannon to arrive), 1400 Mexican army soldiers led by Gen. Antonio López de Santa Anna attacked the 180 defenders inside the makeshift fort (previously a mission church built by Spain). Advancing in four columns at 6:30 am, they took the Alamo by 8 am losing an estimated 250 soldiers. Among the American casualties were Jim Bowie and Davey Crockett.

column1: Advancing towards Berlin, the leading tanks of US
column3: Advancing towards Berlin, the leading tanks of US 3rd Corps (part of US 1st Army) reach the Rhine River opposite Remagen and find the Ludendorff Bridge there damaged but still standing. Troops are immediately rushed across and a bridgehead is firmly established during the day. Other elements of the US 1st Army complete the capture of Cologne (Koln).

column1: In Liberated France, during the night, German forc
column3: In Liberated France, during the night, German forces from the garrisons in the occupied Channel Islands mount a raid on Granville on the west coast of the Cotentin Peninsula. One small US warship and 4 merchant ships are sunk. The raiders also free 67 German prisoners of war.

column1: U-510 torpedoes eight ships in three hours off the
column3: U-510 torpedoes eight ships in three hours off the coast of Brazil, in what is the most successful single U-boat action of the war. U-510 did not lose a single crew member in it's run of 15 sinkings and 8 damaged ships. It was taken out of service on 10 May, 1945 at St Nazaire, France.

column1: The RAF attacks Le Havre and at the same time give
column3: The RAF attacks Le Havre and at the same time gives the new 4-engine Halifax bomber its debut, although one of the six Halifax's involved is shot down on its return flight by an RAF night fighter.

column1: Hermann Goering creates the German Air Force (the
column3: Hermann Goering creates the German Air Force (the Luftwaffe). Goering had been an ace during WWI where he shot down 22 planes. He also created the Geheime Staatspolizei, or Gestapo.

column1: A peace treaty is concluded between Finland and Ru
column3: A peace treaty is concluded between Finland and Russia, that formally ends the Winter War. The terms of this treaty are harsh for Finland, who are forced to cede the entire Karelia Isthmus, which becomes the Russian Republic of Karelia.

column1: The Battle of Dien Bien Phu occurred between Viet
column3: The Battle of Dien Bien Phu occurred between Viet Minh forces and French airborne and Foreign Legion forces. The battle was fought near the village of Dien Bien Phu in northern Vietnam and became the last battle in the Indochina War which had begun in 1947. The victory by the Viet Minh led to the 1954 Geneva accords, which partitioned Vietnam into a communist Northern and pro-Western South Vietnamese governments. This partition was supposed to be temporary, and the two sides were supposed to be reunited by national elections in 1956. Thus the competition for the whole of Vietnam began, and would escalate into the Vietnam War.

column1: RAF Bomber Command make its first use of the 22,00
column3: RAF Bomber Command make its first use of the 22,000lb ‘Grand Slam’ bomb (measuring 7.7 meters [26 feet 6 inches] by 1.17 meters [3 feet, 10 inches]), wrecking the Bielefeld viaduct. The US 15th Air Force, taking off from Italian airfields, launches a heavy raid (500 bombers) against Regensburg, while the RAF attacks Wuppertal with 400 aircraft.

column1: Born Today: Andrew Jackson (US President),  Ry Coo
column3: Born Today: Andrew Jackson (US President),  Ry Cooder (blues guitarist), Fabio ( :) ), Dee Snider (singer)

column1: U-503 is sunk in the North Atlantic south-east of
column3: U-503 is sunk in the North Atlantic south-east of Newfoundland, in position 45.50N, 48.50W, by depth charges from a US Hudson aircraft (Sqdn VP-82) with 51 dead (all hands lost). U-503 had been commissioned since the previous July and had not sunk or damaged any ships before being sunk.

column1: The Luftwaffe attacks the British Fleet anchorage
column3: The Luftwaffe attacks the British Fleet anchorage at Scapa Flow in the Orkney Islands. This raid causes the death of a British civilian, the first of the war.

column1: The U.S. Third Army takes Koblenz. The Ludendorff
column3: The U.S. Third Army takes Koblenz. The Ludendorff bridge at Remagen, seized by US troops on the 7th March, suddenly collapses, killing dozens of US Army engineers working to reinforce it. The Germans had tried to destroy the bridge before the Allies could could make it across the river, but it wasn't until 10 days later that it finally fell.

column1: Japanese troops, reinforced by the 18th and 56th D
column3: Japanese troops, reinforced by the 18th and 56th Division which had arrived by sea at Rangoon a few days earlier, attack the 6th Chinese Army near Toungoo in Burma.

column1: In the Battle of Picardy, Germany launches the fir
column3: In the Battle of Picardy, Germany launches the first of five major offensives in an attempt to win the war before American troops appear in the trenches. The German advance is finally stopped in late June.

column1: Late in the afternoon after an unsuccessful Italia
column3: Late in the afternoon after an unsuccessful Italian torpedo-aircraft attack, Admiral Iachino's Battleship Littorio and 4 destroyers engage a British convoy sailing to Malta. The convoy protected itself with a smokescreen, but the cruiser HMS Cleopatra was damaged. The British send destroyers in a torpedo attack but the Italians had turned away from the British convoy and sailed for home.

column1: Squeezing German resistance, the Allies advance to
column3: Squeezing German resistance, the Allies advance toward Berlin. From the West the U.S. Third Army crosses the Rhine North of Worms, as the British Second and Canadian First Armies begin their assault across the Rhine above the Ruhr.  While in the East, the Russians reach the outskirts of Danzig and Gotenhafen.

column1: The US Fifth Army's bridgehead at Anzio is bombard
column3: The US Fifth Army's bridgehead at Anzio is bombarded by German heavy long-range guns and Luftwaffe aircraft using guided bombs, causing severe casualties in men, ships and equipment. Persistent US and British attacks against the Gustav Line at Cassino are repulsed by the German defenders. In response to the killing of 35 German soldiers in Rome by the Italian resistance, SS Colonel Herbert Kappler orders the execution of 335 Italians, at least 255 of whom are civilians in reprisal. All are shot by German troops in the Fosse Ardeantine caves outside of Rome.

column1: The U.S. Navy begins the pre-invasion bombardment
column3: The U.S. Navy begins the pre-invasion bombardment of Okinawa firing more than half a million shells and rockets in a week.

column1: The last organized Japanese troops on Iwo Jima mak
column3: The last organized Japanese troops on Iwo Jima make a suicide attack. Total U.S. killed on Iwo Jima is 6,891, with more than 20,000 Japanese being killed and only 216 captured.

column1: The allied bridgehead north of Ruhr is now 700 squ
column3: The allied bridgehead north of Ruhr is now 700 square miles. 16,257 POW's are taken for 6,781 allied casualties in four days. The U.S. Third Army captures Aschaffenburg.

column1: Under the new tactical doctrine of area saturation
column3: Under the new tactical doctrine of area saturation bombing, introduced by Air Vice Marshal Harris, the RAF launches a heavy incendiary attack (234 bombers) against Lübeck on the Baltic that devastates 265 acres of the old city. The RAF lost 13 aircraft and from one of these planes the Germans were able to obtain their first specimen of the GEE equipment (a British hyperbolic, pulse-radar, VHF, invention).  In retaliation for the raid on Lübeck, Hitler orders the Luftwaffe to bomb historic British towns and cities.

column1: Born Today: Cy Young (Baseball), Elle MacPherson (
column3: Born Today: Cy Young (Baseball), Elle MacPherson (model), Jennifer Capriati (Tennis)

column1: The Italian Navy spots a British convoy escorted b
column3: The Italian Navy spots a British convoy escorted by 4 Cruisers and 4 Destroyers and close in. The British ships lure the Italians towards the main body of the Mediterranean Fleet which includes 3 battleships and the Aircraft Carrier HMS Formidable. HMS Formidable launches aircraft which attack and hit the Italian Battleship Vittorio Veneto with a torpedo, although it manages to limp back to Taranto. Later, they also hit the Cruiser Pola which is seriously damaged. The Italians decide to withdraw and detach 2 cruisers and 4 Destroyers to assist the damaged Cruiser Pola. However, the British intercept them and sink the Cruiser Pola and its 2 escort Cruisers Zara and Fiume as well as 2 of the escorting Destroyers. British losses total just 2 aircraft.

column1: Russians troops finally capture Danzig, along with
column3: Russians troops finally capture Danzig, along with 45 U-boats and 10,000 prisoners. Breslau and Glogau are surrounded, 180 miles South East of Berlin. Russian troops cross the Austrian border to the North of Koszeg. German troops of Army Group Weichsel evacuate their last remaining bridgehead at Wollin to the North of Stettin.

column1: German occupation of Western Europe shrinks as the
column3: German occupation of Western Europe shrinks as the Germans start pulling out of Holland. The French First Army crosses the Rhine for first time since Napoleon. The US Third Army reaches Siegen 20 miles East of the Rhine. And in the East he Russians enters German territory near Sopron in Hungary. The Russian capture Ratibor in Upper Silesia.

column1: U.S. Army and Marines (10th USA Army and 4 divisio
column3: U.S. Army and Marines (10th USA Army and 4 divisions) invade Okinawa. Invasion Fleet: 1300 ships and 100,000 men. Kamikaze attacks killed 5,000 US marines. After the fight 11,000 Japanese soldiers  surrendered and 110,000 were killed.

column1: Grant's forces begin a general advance and break t
column3: Grant's forces begin a general advance and break through Lee's lines at Petersburg and Confederate Gen. Ambrose P. Hill is killed. The Confederate Capital in Richmond, VA is evacuated and. Fires and looting break out. The next day, Union troops enter and raise the Stars and Stripes.

column1: Born Today: Washington Irving (writer), Marlon Bra
column3: Born Today: Washington Irving (writer), Marlon Brando (actor), Wayne Newton (singer), Eddie Murphy (comedian)

column1: Japanese aircraft bomb Mandalay in central Burma,
column3: Japanese aircraft bomb Mandalay in central Burma, killing 2,000. They met no opposition from the RAF as all its aircraft had by now been withdrawn to India.

column1: The Battle of the Somme ends. It was a large battl
column3: The Battle of the Somme ends. It was a large battle with more than one million casualties. The Allied forces attempted to break through the German lines buty by the end of the battle they had only gained about six miles after 9 months of fighting. The British used the tank for the first time in this battle with little effect, but the battle is best remembered as a prime example of the futile Allied tactic of frontal assault on defended positions that was the hallmark of fighting on the Western Front. However, during the subsequent months of fighting on the Somme River, British Army tactics evolved from the grim lessons of the first few days to orchestrate effective combined operations between infantry, artillery and air force which were instrumental in eventually achieving total victory over the German Army

column1: 180 Japanese planes from five aircraft carriers at
column3: 180 Japanese planes from five aircraft carriers attack the Royal Navy's base at Colombo in Ceylon. These came from Admiral Nagumo's 1st Air Fleet under Admiral Kondo's Southern Force which was tasked with destroying the Royal Navy's Fleet in the Indian Ocean. However, the British received prior warning and sailed the bulk of their fleet to the Maldives, although the armed merchant cruiser Hector and destroyer Tenedos were sunk. Fifty-three Japanese carrier-aircraft did however locate and sink the Royal Navy's heavy cruisers Dorsetshire and Cornwall, to the south east of Ceylon, in just 22 minutes.

column1: Born Today: Butch Cassidy (outlaw),  Harry Houdini
column3: Born Today: Butch Cassidy (outlaw),  Harry Houdini (magician), Bob Marley (singer), John Ratzenberger (actor)

column1: Confederate surprise attack on Gen. Ulysses S. Gra
column3: Confederate surprise attack on Gen. Ulysses S. Grant's unprepared troops at Shiloh on the Tennessee River results in a bitter struggle with 13,000 Union killed and wounded and 10,000 Confederates, more men than in all previous American wars combined. The president is then pressured to relieve Grant but resists. I can't spare this man

column1: Born Today: William Wordsworth (poet), Francis For
column3: Born Today: William Wordsworth (poet), Francis Ford Coppola (director), Jackie Chan (actor), Tony Dorsett (NFL player)

column1: The battle of East China Sea begins as U.S. aircra
column3: The battle of East China Sea begins as U.S. aircraft from Task Force 58 sink the Japanese super-battleship Yamato in a three-hour battle, 60 miles to the Southeast of Japan. Japanese casualties are reported as 2,488 sailors killed, four destroyers sunk, 58 aircraft destroyed.

column1: HMS Glorious was hit by fire from the German battl
column3: HMS Glorious was hit by fire from the German battle cruiser Scharnhorst, which penetrated the flight deck and exploded in the upper hanger disrupting the attempts to get some aircraft airborne.  A second hit was received which killed most of the bridge crew. Glorious, and her two escorting destroyers, Ardent and Acasta were all sunk in the battle. The only ship that could have come to their aid was the HMS Devonshire, but they did not break radio silence because they were carrying the King of Norway and his ministers and did not want to endanger them.

column1: US-Filipino forces on Bataan Peninsula in the Phil
column3: US-Filipino forces on Bataan Peninsula in the Philippines surrender. 78,000 troops are captured, including 12,000 Americans, but 2,000 escape to Corregidor. This is the largest capitulation in US History. Japanese aircraft sink the British carrier Hermes, the destroyer Vampire and three other warships in Indian Ocean.

column1: The 78,000 captured men from Bataan begin a 65 mil
column3: The 78,000 captured men from Bataan begin a 65 mile march under the hot sun from Mariveles to San Fernando, with little food or water. This was to become known as the 'Bataan Death March'. The Japanese begin landing troops on Cebu Island, which has a combined US-Filipino garrison of 4,500 troops.

column1: Born Today: Frederick I the Warlike (Saxon Leader)
column3: Born Today: Frederick I the Warlike (Saxon Leader), Oleg Cassini (Fashion Designer), Oscar De Ville (Meyer CEO), Boxcar Willie (Country musician)

column1: Rommel makes an attempt to capture Tobruk off the
column3: Rommel makes an attempt to capture Tobruk off the march. However, the 9th Australian Division repulses the attack, forcing the Germans to think again. By now the Germans are pretty exhausted after 3 weeks of continuous action and their vehicles in serious need of an overhaul.

column1: Born Today: Tom Clancy (Author) ,  David Letterman
column3: Born Today: Tom Clancy (Author) ,  David Letterman (TV Host), David Cassidy (Singer), Herbie Hancock (Musician)

column1: On the Eastern Front, both German and Russian forc
column3: On the Eastern Front, both German and Russian forces pause for breath after an extremely difficult winter (temperatures dropped to a nippy Minus 30C). The Russians have outrun their supply lines and exhausted their supply store of tanks and guns, which has allowed the initiative to slip back to the Germans. However, the Germans are aware that they can no longer take Moscow with a knockout blow and so choose another alternative. They intend to drive southward as part of a grand pincer movement through the Caucasus to link up with Rommel's Afrika Corps, which will solve their oil problems, disable the Russian economy, and menace the Middle East.

column1: British Naval forces, this time supported by the B
column3: British Naval forces, this time supported by the Battleship HMS Warspite, again engage the German naval forces located at Narvik in the Jössing Fjord. This, the 2nd Battle of Narvik, results in the sinking of 7 German destroyers and a U-boat whose surviving crews join Gebirgsjäger units that are defending isolated Narvik.

column1: As a symbolic end to the War Between the States, t
column3: As a symbolic end to the War Between the States, the Stars and Stripes is ceremoniously raised over Fort Sumter. That night, Lincoln and his wife Mary see the play Our American Cousin at Ford's Theater. At 10:13 p.m., during the third act of the play, John Wilkes Booth shoots President Lincoln in the head. Doctors attend to the president in the theater then move him to a house across the street. He never regains consciousness.

column1: The Canadian First Army reaches the coast in north
column3: The Canadian First Army reaches the coast in northern Holland, captures Arnhem in the South, and begins the liberation of the Netherlands. The US First Army captures Leuna and Merseburg in Saxony, while the French First Army captures Kehl and Offenburg on the upper Rhine.

column1: Hitler issues the last Order of the Day to the Eas
column3: Hitler issues the last Order of the Day to the Eastern Front, saying ‘He who gives orders to retreat . . . is to be shot on the spot’ as the 1st Belorussian Front and the 1st Ukrainian Front start the final offensive on Berlin from along the Oder-Neisse line.

column1: The RAF makes a daylight air raid against Augsburg
column3: The RAF makes a daylight air raid against Augsburg in southern Germany with 14 Lancaster bombers. The raid is pressed home with great gallantry, with squadron leader J.D. Nettleton being awarded the Victoria Cross. However, 7 aircraft are lost, which convinces Air Marshal Harris that daylight raids by heavy bombers were too costly.

column1: American P-38s from the 13th Air Force launched fr
column3: American P-38s from the 13th Air Force launched from Guadalcanal, fly to Bougainvillea and shoot down Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto's plane and killed him.

column1: The Battle of Lexington and Concord was the first
column3: The Battle of Lexington and Concord was the first battle of the American Revolutionary War, marking the shot heard around the world. 700 British regulars, mainly from the flank and grenadier companies, marched from Boston to Lexington and Concord. The British drove the 70 Minutemen from the towns but were ambushed during their return march, beginning the Siege of Boston.

column1: Born Today: Adolph Hitler (Dictator),  Carmen Elec
column3: Born Today: Adolph Hitler (Dictator),  Carmen Electra (Actress?), Luther Vandross (Singer), Joey Lawrence (Actor)

column1: 46 Spitfires arrive on Malta as reinforcement, alt
column3: 46 Spitfires arrive on Malta as reinforcement, although the intensity of the axis air onslaught (9,599 sorties in April) is so intense that almost all these aircraft are destroyed on the ground within 3 days.

column1: The first U-boat tanker or 'Milch cow', U-459, set
column3: The first U-boat tanker or 'Milch cow', U-459, sets sail for the Atlantic. Her role was to prolong the time that U-boats could spend in US waters by refueling and re-arming them at sea.

column1: Baron Manfred Albrecht von Richthofen, the Red Bar
column3: Baron Manfred Albrecht von Richthofen, the Red Baron, was shot down and killed over Morlancourt Ridge, near the Somme River. He was hit by a bullet, shot from behind or below, passing diagonally through his chest. Richthofen may have been shot by Captain Roy Brown, but it is more likely that he was killed by ground fire from Australian Army anti-aircraft machine gunners. Baron von Richthofen is still regarded today as the ace of aces. He was a very talented airplane pilot, who won 80 air combats during World War I.

column1: During the Chilean Civil War, the Chilean naval ve
column3: During the Chilean Civil War, the Chilean naval vessel Almirante Lynch torpedoed and sank the rebel Chilean armored vessel Blanco Encalada with a 14 inch torpedo at the close range of one hundred yards making it the first vessel to be sunk by a torpedo in the current sense of the word. During the American Civil War, stationary mines were called torpedos, as in Admiral David Farragut's famous quote, Damn the torpedoes! Full speed ahead!

column1: On his last patrol aboard U-404, Kapitänleutnant O
column3: On his last patrol aboard U-404, Kapitänleutnant Otto von Bülow fires two FAT and two G7e torpedoes at British aircraft carrier HMS Biter. All detonate prematurely and HMS Biter escapes without damage. Von Bülow is later decorated by Hitler with Oak leaves to his Knights Cross for his Atlantic successes and German newspapers report the recent sinking of the American carrier USS Ranger as well. Later, USS Ranger commander Gordon Rowe, is photographed aboard his carrier smiling at a photograph of von Bülow and the German report of his vessel's demise.

column1: French launch disastrous offensive at Chemin des D
column3: French launch disastrous offensive at Chemin des Dames, advancing only 500 yards at the cost of 250,000 plus casualties.

column1: German planes spot an Allied convoy west of Start
column3: German planes spot an Allied convoy west of Start Point along the Channel Coast. The convoy is actually making a practice run ('Operation Tiger') for the planned invasion of Normandy on a stretch of coast very much like that found in the Normandy region of France. The 5th and 9th Schnellbootflottillers are directed to attack at night, which they do with the following boats: S100, S130, S138, S138, S140, S142, S143, S145, S150. They engage the convoy, consisting of 8 landing craft and protected by the lone English Corvette Azeala at Lyme Bay. The result is that LST 507 was set on fire and had to be given up, LST 531 was sunk and LST 289 received a torpedo hit which killed many soldiers. Total Allied losses were 197 seaman and 441 soldiers lost.

column1: The U.S. Fifth Army take Brescia, 30 miles East of
column3: The U.S. Fifth Army take Brescia, 30 miles East of Milan. The British Eighth Army reaches Venice. Italian Partisans capture Mussolini, his mistress Clara Petacci and 12 of his cabinet members in a German convoy trying to reach Switzerland. All are shot in nearby village.

column1: Convoy RA-66 sailing from the Kola Peninsula to Lo
column3: Convoy RA-66 sailing from the Kola Peninsula to Loch Ewe is attacked by at least 2 U-boats north of Kola. The British destroyer HMS Goodall, which was lend-leased by the US in 1943 is sunk by U-286 (Oblt.z.S. Willi Dietrich), for 1,150 tons, marking this as the last convoy to come under attack in the war.

column1: Operation Mincemeat was a highly successful Allied
column3: Operation Mincemeat was a highly successful Allied deception plan against Axis Forces. The operation involved releasing a dead man in a life jacket off the coast of Spain. A briefcase attached to the body contained fake documents identifying the man as a Major William Martin and copies of fake Allied war plans which stated that the Allies were planning an invasion of Sardinia, rather than Sicily. Local fishermen pulled out the corpse and intelligence materials. The documents were sent to Axis commanders and who were fooled by them. This information quickly reached Hitler who, on 12 May, demanded that measures regarding Sardinia and the Peloponnese take precedence over everything else. column3: During the Falklands War the HMS Sheffield had been ordered forward with two other Type 42 destroyers. Refuelled by a C-130 Hercules shortly after launch, they went in at low altitude, popped up for a radar check and released the missiles from 20 to 30 miles (30 to 50 km) away. One missed HMS Yarmouth, due to her deployment of chaff, but the other hit the Sheffield and set her on fire, killing 22 sailors onboard. The HMS Sheffield was abandoned and sank on May 10th.

Having conquered nearly all of Southeast Asia in just a few months, Japan was at the apex of its power. But the upcoming Battle of the Coral Sea (on May 7) was not an easy Japanese victory. In tactical terms, the Japanese had had a narrow victory: one small carrier lost and a large carrier damaged, against the loss of a large carrier and equivalent damage to another. But from the Allied point of view, after five months of continuous defeat, a battle that came out almost even was close enough to a victory as not to matter.

When Kptlt. Fehler heard of the cease-fire orders on 4 May 1945, he decides to surrender to the Americans, rather than the Canadians, being in a relatively equal position to do either. column1: Polish troops hoist their red-white flag on the ru
column3: Polish troops hoist their red-white flag on the ruins of Monte Cassino.In 24 days of hard fighting, impregnable Cassino fell, two German armies were defeated, 20,000 prisoners were taken, three defensive lined were smashed, and vast quantities of German material were destroyed. column1: A busy day for Soviet partisans, who blast railway
column3: A busy day for Soviet partisans, who blast railway tracks between Bryansk and Roslavl at five points. An irritated Josef Goebbels diaries In consequence, we can hardly get any agricultural work done in such regions. The German 6th Army launches an offensive to the North of the Russian salient in order to link hands with Kleist’s Panzer’s who have ripped a 50 mile gap through the Red Army’s flank. With the Germans cutting off the Russian Barvenkovo offensive from their rear, the Russian cancel their offensive, do a fast U-turn and try to fight their way out of the pocket and back to safety. Unfortunately, the attack is badly organized and uncoordinated.

column1: Operation Merkur: German troops invade the British
column3: Operation Merkur: German troops invade the British-held island of Crete.The full German assault on Crete commences with air attacks followed by paratroops dropped on the four airfields. column3: A British counter attack is launched near Arras with armoured and infantry support against Rommel's 7th Panzer Division, throwing it off balance. The French Ninth Army is surrounded and destroyed, its commander, General Giraud, taken prisoner.

column3: Bismark Part 1 British flying boat spots the German Battleship Bismarck at 10:36am. Swordfish Torpedo-bombers from the Ark Royal score hits on the Bismarck, disabling her steering gear and rendering her un-maneuverable. This enables British destroyers to attack after dark...

column3: Bismark Part 2 400 miles west of Brest, the Battleship Bismarck is relentlessly bombarded by dozens of British warships, including the battleships Rodney and King George V. column3: The rest of the Japanese forces directed at Midway set out. In Hawaii Task Force 16 sails from Oahu for Midway with the carriers Enterprise and Hornet and escorts. Admiral Fletcher's Task Force 17 follows after miraculously quick repairs to the  Yorktown.

column3: The British destroyer HMS Wakeful is hit and sunk by a torpedo from the German E-boat S30. HMS Grafton which was nearby try's to rescue the sailors from HMS Wakeful, but is itself hit by another torpedo from the same German E-boat and begins to sink. Another British destroyer, HMS Comfort moves up to help, but HMS Grafton fires on her in the mistaken believe that she is a German ship, sinking HMS comfort. 15 other vessels are also sunk by Luftwaffe Stuka attacks near Dunkirk on this day.

column1: 53,823 British and French troops are evacuated fro
column3: 53,823 British and French troops are evacuated from Dunkirk, bringing total landed in England since May 27th to 126,606. Under the command of Admiral Bertram Ramsay, hundreds of naval, commercial and private vessels participate in this most desperate rescue attempt. Calais falls to the Germans as they advance towards Dunkirk after Hitler's stop order is rescinded.

column1: By the end of May, 41 U-boats have been sunk in th
column3: By the end of May, 41 U-boats have been sunk in the Atlantic due to greatly improved allied anti-submarine techniques and tactics (Hedgehog, greater-range patrol aircraft, better radar, more escort vessels and carriers, plus the advantage of having broken the German Navy Enigma code). Black May effectively marks the end of a sustained German U-boat campaign in WW2 which did come very close to starving out Britain and forcing her to make terms with Germany.

column1: Rommel takes the fortified ‘box’ that is held by t
column3: Rommel takes the fortified ‘box’ that is held by the British 150th Brigade in the Gazala defensive line and secures the 'Cauldron'. This enables him to get much needed supplies flowing. Rommel now turns the German 90th Light Division and the Italian Ariete Armoured Division against Bir Hacheim in an attempt to wipe out the Free French garrison which still holds out. He also distracts the British by sending the 21st Panzer Division northeast to operate nearer to Tobruk.

US land based aircraft from Midway spot the Japanese Transport Force about 600 miles from Midway. They launch attacks against this force, but without success. US reconnaissance aircraft spot the 2 carriers of the Japanese 2nd Carrier Striking Force, which were about 400 miles from Kiska in the Aleutians.

column3: The Eighth Army launches a counter-attack against the Afrika Korps forces that are inside the 'Cauldron'. This is codenamed 'Aberdeen', but went disastrously wrong from the start, with an infantry tank brigade being destroyed in minefields and an Indian infantry brigade attacking the wrong positions. This left the remainder of the force, the 22nd Armoured Brigade to be repulsed easily by the untouched German defenses. British losses for this operation were 150 tanks, 133 guns and 6,000 troops.

column1: Before dawn, the Allied Expeditionary Force of Bri
column3: Before dawn, the Allied Expeditionary Force of British, American, Canadian, Polish, and Free French troops begins Operation Overlord, the long-awaited invasion of France. After an intensive naval and aerial bombardment, the first wave of 5 divisions (156,115 men) are landed at designated beaches in Normandy named Sword, Juno, Gold, Omaha and Utah. This is preceded by the British 6th Airborne Division which lands near Caen and some 12,000 paratroopers of the US 82nd and 101st Airborne Divisions which are dropped on the Cotentin peninsula. These forces are supported by 1,213 warships, including 7 battleships and 23 cruisers, 1,600 auxiliary ships, and 4,126 landing craft, as well as massive British and American air support, which fly’s 14,674 sorties that day. Opposing them in their bunkers and on the beaches are 5 German infantry divisions with about 50,000 men and 100 tanks and assault guns. Despite some heavy casualties, especially by the American’s on Omaha Beach, the German defenders, stunned and surprised by the massive onslaught, are progressively overwhelmed, and most of the allied objectives are reached and secured by nightfall. There is very little opposition from the Luftwaffe or Kriegsmarine.

It was initially escorted by a battleship, 2 aircraft carriers, 3 cruisers and 8 destroyers and was later reinforced by an anti-aircraft cruiser and 9 destroyers. The Alexandria convoy (codenamed 'Vigorous'), had eleven freighters and was escorted by 7 light cruisers and 26 destroyers.

column1: An Italian naval squadron intercepts the 'Harpoon'
column3: An Italian naval squadron intercepts the 'Harpoon' convoy and disables two British destroyers, as well as damaging the anti-aircraft cruiser HMS Cairo, although the the Italians lost a destroyer in the process. Axis aircraft then attacked and sank 2 freighters, the tanker Kentucky and 1 destroyer. Another Italian naval squadron had sailed from Taranto to intercept convoy 'Vigorous', which reversed course in the face of this threat. While it was doing this, German E-boats moved in and sank a destroyer and damaged a cruiser with torpedos. At this point British torpedo aircraft from Malta attacked the Italian naval squadron, disabling a cruiser, which was later sunk by a British submarine. In the meantime 'Vigorous' turned towards Malta again, but further reports of the Italian naval squadron steaming south, forced another course reversal. German Stukas then attacked the convoy and damaged a cruiser and sank a destroyer. The Italian naval squadron moved now moved north, removing the threat to the 'Vigorous' convoy, but Admiral Vian commanding the 'Vigorous' convoy decided that he did not have enough ammunition left to resume his course to Malta and so continued back to Alexandria, during which U-205 sank the cruiser HMS Hermione south of Crete and Stukas sank another destroyer. However, as consolation, British aircraft did manage to torpedo the Italian Battleship Littorio, which spent the next two months under repair.

column3: The French front begins cracking as the Germans break through in Champagne to Dijon, with units of 19th Panzer Korps reaching Besancon on the Swiss border. The French government of Paul Reynaud resigns and is replaced by one led by Marshal Petain who immediately appoints Weygand as Minister of National Defence. 57,000 British troops are evacuated from Nantes and St. Nazaire.

column1: Plans for the offensive in to the Caucasus are cap
column3: Plans for the offensive in to the Caucasus are captured by the Russians when a staff officer from the 23rd Panzer Division is shot down. Against all orders, he was carrying the plans on his person. 40th Panzer Corps commander, General Stumme and his chief of staff are immediately imprisoned on Hitlers express orders. No changes were made to the plan as although the Russians considered them authentic, they believed that it was only a subsidiary thrust and that the main objective was still Moscow, which suited the Germans.

column1: In the Philippine Sea the Japanese fleet withdraws
column3: In the Philippine Sea the Japanese fleet withdraws to refuel, believing that their aircraft have landed safely on Guam. US Task Force 58 (Admiral Mitscher) launches an air strike on the Japanese fleet in the late afternoon. The 216 American aircraft encounter 35 defending fighters and sink the carrier Hiyo. Two other Japanese aircraft carriers are damaged as are a battleship and a cruiser. US loses amount to 20 planes shot down and 72 crashing while attempting to land on their carriers in the dark. During the night, the Japanese fleet withdraws and are not pursued.

column1: Organized resistance on Okinawa ends after 82 days
column3: Organized resistance on Okinawa ends after 82 days of the bloodiest fighting in the Pacific, during which 98,654 Japanese have been killed and 6,922 captured. U.S. loses were 6,990 killed and 29,598 wounded.

column3: Germans troops cross the River Loire in strength as an armistice between France and Germany is signed at Compiegne. Its terms are read out loud to the French delegation by Generaloberst Keitel and provide for the occupation of the entire Channel and Atlantic coastlines, all major industrial areas, Alsace-Lorraine is to be returned to Germany. Most of southern France will remain unoccupied, with a French administrative centre at Vichy. The French Army and Navy is to be demobilized and disarmed and France is to bear the cost of the German occupation. All French prisoners of war are to remain in Germany until a peace treaty is signed.

column3: The Soviet attack begins. The Soviet combat forces directly engaged in the offensive amount to over 1,250,000 men (in 124 divisions), over 4000 tanks and self-propelled guns, over 24,000 artillery pieces and over 6300 aircraft. The target of Operation Bagration is German Army Group Center (Busch) holding a salient centered on Minsk.The German defenders amount to 800,000 men in 63 divisions with about 900 tanks and assault guns, 10,000 artillery pieces and 1300 planes. Advances of up 11 miles are recorded by Red Army troops of 2nd, 3rd Belorussian and 1st Baltic Fronts. Meanwhile in the far north, forces of the Soviet 7th Separate Army cross the Svir River.

column1: The village of Levzasky is destroyed in reprisal f
column3: The village of Levzasky is destroyed in reprisal for the assassination of Reichsprotektor Heydrich in Prague by Czechoslovakian resistance fighters with British supplied equipment on May 27th. In total, more than 1,000 people are killed in various reprisals.

column3: The Democratic People's Republic of Korea Army (DPRK - North Korea) artillery and mortars open fire on Republic of Korea (ROK - South Korea) Army positions south of the 38th Parallel, the line then serving as the border between the two countries. In this announcement North Korea claimed ROK forces on the Ongjin Peninsula attacked North Korea in the Haeju area (west) and their declaration of war was in response to this attack. This claim was bogus.
