column3: Born Today: Charles III, [The Simple] (king of France),  Stirling Moss (race driver), Fee Waybill (rocker - Tubes), Annika Duckmark (Miss Universe)Warren Burger (Supreme Court chief justice), Anne Bancroft (actress), Rasheed Wallace (NBA)

column1: The bloodiest day in U.S. military history as Gen.
column3: The bloodiest day in U.S. military history as Gen. Robert E. Lee and the Confederate Armies are stopped at Antietam in Maryland by McClellan and numerically superior Union forces. By nightfall 26,000 men are dead, wounded, or missing. Lee then withdraws to Virginia. General McClellan underestimated his numerical advantage and failed to pursue General Lee back into Virginia, guaranteeing long years of battles to come.

column1: In Russia, the government conscripts all men aged
column3: In Russia, the government conscripts all men aged 16 - 50. Units of Army Group South capture Poltava in the Ukraine. The Russians evacuate Kiev, but the ‘fight to the death’ continues in the area for a week.

column1: In Poland, less than 3 weeks after the start of WW
column3: In Poland, less than 3 weeks after the start of WWII, the battle of the Vistula bend ends with the Wehrmacht taking 170,000 prisoners. Lavrenti Beria, chief of the Soviet NKVD, sets up a Directorate for Prisoners of War and establishes camps for the 240,000 Polish POWs in Soviet custody

column1: In Holland, Operation Market Garden continues. A j
column3: In Holland, Operation Market Garden continues. A joint attack by the British Guards Armored Division and the US 82nd Airborne Division captures Nijmegen and the bridge over the Waal River. At Arnhem, the British 1st Airborne Division is forced away from the bridge by German forces.

column1: Born Today: HG Wells (author),, Neil Peart (Rush d
column3: Born Today: HG Wells (author),, Neil Peart (Rush drummer), Bill Murray (actor), Stephen King (author)

column1: The British under General Howe sailed from New Yor
column3: The British under General Howe sailed from New York to attempt the capture of Philadelphia, then the American capital. They had earlier landed at the head of Chesapeake Bay, putting them within fifty miles of Philadelphia. Major-General Charles 'No Flint' Grey ordered his troops to remove the flints from their muskets (hence, the nickname), to remove the danger that any of his men might fire and give away their position. Just after midnight the British found that the Americans had failed to post an adequate guard, and the surprise was near-total. The British troops stormed into the sleeping American camp, causing absolute chaos. The musket was a slow weapon to load and fire, and the bayonet-armed British troops were able to inflict very heavy loses on the Americans while themselves suffering very little. Over four hundred Americans were killed, wounded or captured, while the British suffered only eight killed out of a total of twenty casualties.

column1: Born Today: Michael Faraday (scientist),  Ronaldo
column3: Born Today: Michael Faraday (scientist),  Ronaldo (Soccer:Brazil), Joan Jett (Singer), Bilbo Baggins (hobbit :)), Allan Lane (voice of Mr Ed)

column1: Nathan Hale is hanged for espionage by the British
column3: Nathan Hale is hanged for espionage by the British, where he supposedly said, I only regret that I have but one life to lose for my country.

column1: In the Yap Islands, part of the US 81st Division o
column3: In the Yap Islands, part of the US 81st Division occupies Ulithi Atoll after naval reconnaissance suggests it is not in use by the Japanese. Work begins on converting the atoll into a major American naval base.

column1: The first German U-boat passes Gilbraltar, enterin
column3: The first German U-boat passes Gilbraltar, entering the Mediterranean Sea. Also, Operation Halberd is launched on this day, by the Allies, to carry supplies to Malta. The initial convoy is nine transports with an escort of three battleships, one carrier, five cruisers and eighteen destroyers.

column1: Operation Market Garden ends. The remnants of the
column3: Operation Market Garden ends. The remnants of the British 1st Airborne Division are evacuated from the north bank of the Rhine. During the night, 2400 of the 10,000 men are removed. About 1100 have been killed and 6400 captured by German forces. A few are sheltered by Dutch families. Meanwhile, other elements of British 2nd Army capture Helmond and Deurne, a few miles east of Eindhoven. On the Channel coast, the Canadian 3rd Division (an element of Canadian 1st Army) attacks the German garrison trapped in Calais.

column1: Born Today: TS Eliot (author),  Johnny Appleseed (
column3: Born Today: TS Eliot (author),  Johnny Appleseed (environmentalist), Linda Hamilton (actress), Serena Williams (tennis)

column1: The German 8th Army, under the command of the Germ
column3: The German 8th Army, under the command of the German Army Commander in Chief, von Brauchitsch, joins the attack on Warsaw. There is a massive artillery bombardment of Warsaw, followed by a major German infantry assault, leaving the city center in flames. Poles recapture Mokotow Airport and 6 hastily rebuilt aircraft fly out during the night

column1: The German pocket Battleships, Admiral Graf Spee a
column3: The German pocket Battleships, Admiral Graf Spee and Deutschland, which had sailed from Germany in August, are given orders to attack allied shipping in the Atlantic. From September through December 1939 Admiral Graf Spee sank nine merchant ships in the South Atlantic and Indian Ocean, the first on September 30, 1939. The captain of the Admiral Graf Spee strictly adhered to the rules of mercantile warfare at the time, and saved all of the crew members of these ships

column1: The Battle of Hastings is one of the few truly dec
column3: The Battle of Hastings is one of the few truly decisive battles in history. On a single day Duke William of Normandy led his motley army against one of the strongest and wealthiest kingdoms in eleventh century Europe. William the Conqueror's conquest altered the whole outlook of England, taking a nation that had looked towards Scandinavia, especially under three Danish kings, and locking her into a partnership and a struggle with France that was to last for centuries.

column1: The Soviet-British-US conference in Moscow conclud
column3: The Soviet-British-US conference in Moscow concludes with a protocol being signed committing the Britain and the USA to supply Russia with 400 aircraft immediately and 500 aircraft per month until the 30th June 1942. There-after the protocol would be renewable annually. Further, both countries undertook to deliver 41,000 tons of Aluminium immediately and 6,000 tons of rubber and 1,500 tons of tin per month. Food and medical supplies were also included.

column1: The ocean liner Queen Mary, in service as a troop
column3: The ocean liner Queen Mary, in service as a troop transport, collides with the British cruiser Curacao sinking the cruiser. The liners traveled without escort, depending upon speed for safety. Escorts were provided for these ships only within British coastal waters.

column1: The first Me262 jet fighter becomes operational. T
column3: The first Me262 jet fighter becomes operational. The Messerschmitt Me 262 Schwalbe (Swallow) was the first operational jet powered fighter. It saw action from late 1944 in bomber/reconnaissance and fighter/interceptor roles. German pilots nicknamed it the Turbo, while to the Allies it was the Stormbird. The 262's top speed was 540 mph compared to the Spitfire's 374 mph. The 262 had a negligible impact on the course of the war—shooting down an estimated 150 Allied aircraft for the loss of 100 Me 262s.

column1: Hitler enters Warsaw in triumph 3 days after Polis
column3: Hitler enters Warsaw in triumph 3 days after Polish forces surrendered. The Soviet Union forces a treaty on Latvia that allows the Red Navy to establish bases in her Baltic harbors.

column1: Operation Basalt was a small raid on the German oc
column3: Operation Basalt was a small raid on the German occupied British Channel Island of Sark. It was conducted by ten men of the Special Operations Executive, often called the Baker Street Irregulars. The raid netted one German, but several were killed after capture. This prompted Hitler's Commando Order which stated that all enemy commandos be executed instead of taken prisoner.

column1: 105 BC – The Battle of Arausio took place between
column3: 105 BC – The Battle of Arausio took place between the town of Arausio and the Rhone River (southern France). Ranged against the migratory tribes of the Cimbri and the Teutoni were two Roman armies, commanded by the proconsul Quintus Servilius Caepio and consul Gnaeus Manlius Maximus. However, bitter differences between the commanders prevented the Roman armies from cooperating with devastating results. Roman losses are quoted at up to 80,000 troops, and many more servants and camp followers (total loss estimated at about 112,000 men).

column1: While anchored in Bahia, Brazil, the Confederate s
column3: While anchored in Bahia, Brazil, the Confederate ship CSS Florida, was raided by the forces of Commander Napoleon Collins of USS Wachusett while her captain was ashore with half his crew. Towed to sea, she was sent to the United States as a prize despite Brazil's protests at this violation of neutral rights.

column1: The Battle of Perryville was fought in the Chaplin
column3: The Battle of Perryville was fought in the Chaplin Hills west of Perryville, Kentucky. The battle began with a middle-of-the-night skirmish over a source of precious drinking water, and ended more or less by default with the onset of darkness and the retreat of the tactical victor, the Confederates. It marked the end of the Kentucky Campaign of Confederate Generals Braxton Bragg and Edmund Kirby Smith and, like the campaign, was marked not only by fierce fighting and heroic achievement, but also by indecision, confusion, and futility on both sides.

column1: Hitler announces that the war in the East, for all
column3: Hitler announces that the war in the East, for all intents and purposes, has already been decided in favor of the Reich. - President Roosevelt in a message to Congress urges the repeal of Section 6 of the Neutrality Act which would allow the arming of U.S. merchant ships against the modern pirates of the sea, the U-boats.

column1: Soviet General Zhukov is called to Moscow from Len
column3: Soviet General Zhukov is called to Moscow from Leningrad to assume control of the defense of the capital city. Zhukov's successful Soviet counter-offensive drove the Germans out of reach of the Soviet capital. His logistics are considered by some to be his greatest achievement.

column1: In a night encounter near Guadalcanal off of Cape
column3: In a night encounter near Guadalcanal off of Cape Esperance, an American force of 4 cruisers and 4 destroyers meets a Japanese force of 3 cruisers and 2 destroyers. Despite the advantages of radar and better radio communications, the American fare as poorly as the Japanese, both at times firing on their own vessels. The Americans lose a destroyer and two cruisers in the fighting. The Japanese lose a cruiser and a destroyer with the two other cruisers badly damaged. Despite the battle, the Japanese manage to land artillery and tanks at their positions.

column1: A British Liberator bomber sinks German U-boat U-5
column3: A British Liberator bomber sinks German U-boat U-597. It is the first success scored by the single RAF squadron of long range bombers. Despite their usefulness, the Liberator is reserved for strategic bombing missions over Europe and will not be used in quantity in the Atlantic for some time.

column1: Chinese artillery is secretly transported deep beh
column3: Chinese artillery is secretly transported deep behind Japanese lines to shell Ichang Airfield which is a base used by for Japanese air raids on Chungking.

column1: U47 sinks HMS Royal Oak at anchor in Scapa Flow, k
column3: U47 sinks HMS Royal Oak at anchor in Scapa Flow, killing 883. U47 then escapes undetected and returns home to Germany. The press in Germany declare Kapitanleutnant Prien a hero. Polish submarine Orzel arrives in Britain having escaped internment in Estonia.

column1: The Hungarian chief of state, Admiral Horthy, shor
column3: The Hungarian chief of state, Admiral Horthy, shortly after announcing Hungary's withdrawal from the war against the Russia, is taken prisoner by a commando unit led by SS major Otto Skorzeny. A new government under Ferenc Szalasi vows to continue the alliance with Germany.

column1: The Japanese mount another air attack on Allied po
column3: The Japanese mount another air attack on Allied positions in Oro Bay in New Guinea and sustain heavy losses in aircraft and crew. The Japanese counteroffensive around Finschafen continues to be held by Australian forces.

column1: On the Eastern Front it is announced in Moscow tha
column3: On the Eastern Front it is announced in Moscow that the 4th Ukrainian Front (Petrov) has entered Czechoslovakia. German forces from Greece and southern Yugoslavia are rapidly falling back to avoid being cut off by advancing Soviet forces.The call up for the Volksturm begins in Germany, with all able-bodied men from 16 to 60 to be conscripted.

column1: Convoy HX-79 (49 ships), sailing from Halifax in C
column3: Convoy HX-79 (49 ships), sailing from Halifax in Canada to Britain, is attacked by 5 U-boats between the 19th and 20th in the North Atlantic. The British lost 12 ships for 75,063 gross tons, while not a single U-boat was lost. The destroyer Venetia sinks after hitting mine in Thames Estuary.

column1: In the Philippines elements of the US 6th Army lan
column3: In the Philippines elements of the US 6th Army land on the east coast of Leyte. 1st Cavalry and 24th Infantry of the US 10th come ashore to the south of Tacloban

column1: The death of the Warlord Toyotomi Hideyoshi, who h
column3: The death of the Warlord Toyotomi Hideyoshi, who has risen far from his peasant beginnings, but because of them could not claim the title of Shogun leaves two main rivals for power, Ishida Mitsunari and Tokugawa Ieyasu. Their struggle was to be finally decided in a small mountain valley in central Japan. Fog lifted from the battlefield at 8am on 10/21/1600, with each commander having about 60,000 men. Tokugawa matchlock gunners (Teppo-tai) caused great damage as the battle continued, the enemy gunners also returned fire filling the valley with smoke and the screams of the dying. By 10am despite their efforts the Tokugawa forces were slowly being driven back, Mitsunari now signalled Kobayakawa Hideaki with his 15,000 fresh troops to attack but nothing happened, the Mori clan had abandoned him. Hideaki forces did not attack their former allies either but sat on the side lines waiting until Ieyasu forced his hand by directing some musket fire on the Mori clan troops. Finally Kobayakawa attacks bringing with him four other generals who decide to change sides and the turncoats fall upon Ishida's rear deciding the battle. By the end of the battle 40,000 had died and Ieyasu was master of Japan, 3 years later to become Shogun.

column1: Born Today: Franz Liszt (composer),  Annette Funic
column3: Born Today: Franz Liszt (composer),  Annette Funicello (mouseketeer), Curly (stooge #3), Jeff Goldblum (actor)

column1: Hitler meets General Franco at Hendaye in southern
column3: Hitler meets General Franco at Hendaye in southern France. Hitler tries to persuade Franco to join the war and offers as bait the allocation of Gibraltar and territory in North Africa. Franco is uncertain about how to proceed and successfully muddles the issue, leaving Hitler no better informed as to what is Spanish policy but without causing offense.

column1: In the Battle of Leyte Gulf in the Philipines, Jap
column3: In the Battle of Leyte Gulf in the Philipines, Japanese aircraft based on Luzon attack US Task Group 38.3 critically damaging the carrier Princeton. The Japanese Center Force is discovered by scout planes from US Task Group 38.2 and attacked throughout the day by all the carrier groups. The Japanese battleship Musashi is sunk and a cruiser is damaged and turns back. The Japanese Southern Force is also sighted but American air strikes fail to cause significant damage.

column1: In North Africa, Montgomery switches the attack to
column3: In North Africa, Montgomery switches the attack to the North. Field Marshal Rommel breaks off his sick leave to take charge of the critical situation in which the Afrikakorps finds itself as a result of the British 8th Army's massive offensive at El Alamein.

column1: The Battle of Santa Cruz in the Solomon Islands se
column3: The Battle of Santa Cruz in the Solomon Islands sees both American and Japanese forces launching at dawn. Both attacks have been launched at the extreme edge of the aircrafts' range and the Japanese have the advantage as their range is longer and they reach and seriously damages the USS Hornet. When the American planes find part of the Japanese force, there is not enough fuel left for an organized attack, however, the cruiser  Chikuma is damaged. The remainder of the planes attack the carrier Shokaku and damage it heavily. A second wave of Japanese attackers severely damages the USS  Enterprise but many of the planes are shot down by the antiaircraft guns of the  South Dakota. The third wave of Japanese planes from the Junyo suffer the same fate. The battle is considered a Japanese victory. The damaged USS  Enterprise is now the only American carrier in the Pacific. However, the victory is costly as again loss of Japanese aircrew is high and the lost of aircraft has removed the ffectiveness of the undamaged aircraft carrier Zuikaku.

column1: In the American Revolutionary War, General William
column3: In the American Revolutionary War, General William Howe's British army was completing their occupation of New York. George Washington had withdrawn to the high ground near the village of White Plains. Washington was forced to withdraw, however, Howe missed the chance to force a larger engagement that could destroy Washington's army. After taking the high ground, he paused to set up camp and artillery batteries. After spending a few miserable nights on swampy ground under the British guns, the Americans slipped away to the north, escaping with their wounded and supplies.

column1: Great Dutch naval victory over the Spanish during
column3: Great Dutch naval victory over the Spanish during the Thirty Years War. A great Spanish Armada of 75 ships, containing 13,000 recruits bound for Flanders from Spain was intercepted by a much smaller Dutch fleet of 18 ships under Admiral Maarten Tromp. On 16 September the Dutch first attacked and forced the Spanish to withdraw. A second attack on 18 September by a now reinforced Dutch fleet forced the Spanish to flee into neutral English waters and seek shelter in the Downs roadstead. While a weak English squadron attempted to prevent any fighting, Tromp resupplied, and on 21 October launched an attack into neutral waters. English attempts at protecting the Spanish were ineffective, and Tromp inflicted a crushing defeat on the Spanish fleet. Seventy Spanish ships were sunk or captured. The battle destroyed what remained of Spanish naval power, seriously weakened their position in Flanders, and gave the Dutch undesputed naval supremacy. Despite ignoring English neutrality, Tromp was knighted by Charles I in 1642.

column1: In Italy, the US 5th Army captures Mondragone on t
column3: In Italy, the US 5th Army captures Mondragone on the west coast after penetrating the German Barbara Line defenses in the area. Other elements of the army, further inland, continue their advance.

column1: In the north Atlantic, the US destroyer Reuben Jam
column3: In the north Atlantic, the US destroyer Reuben James escorting Convoy HX-156 is sunk by U-552 (Kapitänleutnant Erich Topp) with the loss of 100 of her crew. The destroyer is the first US naval casualty in the hitherto undeclared war between Germany and the United States that existed after President Roosevelt authorized the use of American naval vessels to escort Lend-Lease convoys bound for Britain.

column1: In North Africa, Operation Supercharge, planned by
column3: In North Africa, Operation Supercharge, planned by British General Montgomery gets under way. The infantry attacks to clear the last of the minefields are held up and when the British armor advances, the 15th Panzer is prepared and inflicts heavy losses. The British can afford these losses. Rommel cannot. After 21st Panzer joins the attack, he is left with only 35 operational vehicles and little fuel or ammunition. Rommel sends word to Hitler that a British breakthrough is inevitable and withdrawal necessary.

column1: U-31 is sunk NW of Ireland by depth charges from t
column3: U-31 is sunk NW of Ireland by depth charges from the British destroyer HMS Antelope. 2 dead and 44 survivors. This is the second time that U-31 has been sunk! on March 11, 1940 in Jadebusen she was sunk by British Bristol Blenheim aircraft (RAF Bomber Command). 58 dead - all hands lost, but was raised in March 1940, repaired and returned to service.

column1: In North Africa British and Axis forces meet in th
column3: In North Africa British and Axis forces meet in the Battle of El Alamein. Axis forces had begun to retreat but are stopped when Hitler's order is received (Field Marshal Rommel had proposed to withdraw the Afrika Korps, now down to about 40 tanks, to the Fuka line, Hitler orders him to stand and fight.) The Italians are already in the process of withdrawal. The British are unable to continue to pressure the beleaguered troops, much to Rommel's surprise. They are having difficulty moving men and equipment through the minefields at a rapid pace.

column1: In the Balkans the first Greek counterattacks begi
column3: In the Balkans the first Greek counterattacks begin in the northern sector of the front. The Italian offensive, despite its numerical strength, is already in difficulties.

column1: The German pocket battleship Admiral Scheer finds
column3: The German pocket battleship Admiral Scheer finds the British convoy HX-84 of 37 ships while on a sortie into the Atlantic. As this point in its route the convoy is only escorted by a single armed merchant cruiser, the Jervis Bay, which, although totally outgunned, engages the Admiral Scheer to gain time for the convoy to scatter. Jervis Bay is, of course, sunk but only five ships of the convoy fail to get away. The British suspend convoy sailings until November 17th but their pursuit fails to find the German ship which has moved toward the south Atlantic.

column1: Halted before Ordshonikidse in the Caucasus, the 1
column3: Halted before Ordshonikidse in the Caucasus, the 13th Panzer Division is fighting to prevent itself being cut off by superior Soviet forces attacking its flanks and rear. In a speech to the Congress of Soviet Deputies, Stalin warns the United States and Britain that 'the absence of a second front against Fascist Germany may end badly for all freedom loving countries, including the Allies themselves'. He declares that 'the aim of the coalition is to save mankind from reversion to savagery and mediaeval brutality'.

column1: In the Solomon Islands US Task Force 38 with the c
column3: In the Solomon Islands US Task Force 38 with the carriers Saratoga and Princeton is attacked by 100 Japanese aircraft. The air attack fails to achieve any hits on the carriers. Meanwhile, on Bougainville Island, a Japanese battalion is landed to the north of the beachhead held by the US 3rd Marine Division. A battle ensues. The Japanese reinforce their garrison on Buka Island.

column1: Born Today: Edmund Halley (astronomer - Halley's C
column3: Born Today: Edmund Halley (astronomer - Halley's Comet),  Katharine Hepburn (actress), Milton Bradley (game manufacturer), Tara Reid (actress)

column1: Operation Torch sees the Allies land in French Nor
column3: Operation Torch sees the Allies land in French North Africa. The Western Task Force, commanded by General Patton, is comprised of 35,000 troops and is supported by naval forces of two battleships, one fleet carrier, four escort carriers and numerous cruisers and destroyers. The Central Task Force, commanded by General Fredendall is comprised of 39,000 American troops with naval support of two escort carriers and many smaller ships.The Eastern Task Force, contains 52 warships and 33,000 soldiers, led by General Ryder and Admiral Burroughs. The British contingent, 87th Division is supported by three battleships, three fleet carriers and a strong force of cruisers and destroyers. The Western Task force lands at Casablanca. The Central is to land in and around Oran and the Eastern Task force lands in Algiers. The Eastern force at Algiers makes good early progress and quickly captures the town. A prize prisoner is found in Admiral Darlan, a prominent leader of the Vichy government. At Oran, the Central Force loses two destroyers but eventaully takes the airfield at Tafaraiu. The Western Task force at Casablanca runs into the greatest opposition. In total there are 1800 casualties.

column1: The Japanese hang the Soviet spy Richard Sorge at
column3: The Japanese hang the Soviet spy Richard Sorge at Sugamo Prison in Tokyo. Sorge has been working for 8 years as the Tokyo correspondent for a German newspaper and during that time he has sent detailed information concerning German and Japanese plans to the Soviet Union. Among the information sent is a warning of the German attack on the USSR in 1941.

column1: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill announces
column3: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill announces that should the United States become involved in a war with Japan, a British declaration of war will follow within the hour. The Japanese Foreign Minister says their aim is to make the US and UK retreat from East Asia.

column1: The British Fleet launches an air attack against t
column3: The British Fleet launches an air attack against the Italian fleet at Taranto. Swordfish aircraft from the Aircraft Carrier HMS Illustrious damage three battleships, two cruisers, two destroyers and two auxiliary craft. This British victory, forces the Italians to temporarily withdraw their big surface units to the safer ports on the west coast of Italy.

column1: In Occupied Norway the German battleship Tirpitz i
column3: In Occupied Norway the German battleship Tirpitz is attacked at anchor in Tromsofiord by 21 British Lancaster bombers carrying 12,000-pound Tall-Boy bombs. The planes are from No. 9 and No. 617 Squadrons. The vessel turns over within thirteen minutes of the explosions. A total of 902 German sailors are killed in the attack. Offshore, British Royal Navy cruisers and destroyers attack a German coastal convoy.

column1: U-81, commanded by Kapitänleutnant Friedrich Gugge
column3: U-81, commanded by Kapitänleutnant Friedrich Guggenberger, torpedoes the British aircraft carrier Ark Royal 30 miles off of Gibraltar. Badly damaged she sank the following day with the loss of only one crew member.

column1: Off of Guadalcanal, Admiral Tanaka turns south wit
column3: Off of Guadalcanal, Admiral Tanaka turns south with his destroyers and transports and comes under heavy air attack from both Henderson Field and planes from the USS Enterprise. Seven of the transports and two warships are lost. He continues his advance throughout the night and manages to sail his remaining transports to Tassafaronga. However, more of the Japanese troops are killed by air attack while disembarking. Meanwhile, the second battle of Guadalcanal gets underway shortly before midnight. The Japanese covering force supporting the convoy with the battleship Kirishima, four cruisers and nine destroyers, encounters US Task Force 64, with the battleships  Washington and  South Dakota and four destroyers. The battle begins with damage to the  South Dakota. It is forced from the battle. A seven minute burst of fire from the USS  Washington sinks the Kirishima. Control of the seas around Guadalcanal is passing to the Americans. Supply problems are mounting for the Japanese, who will now be forced to make considerable use of submarines to transport supplies.

column1: In temperatures of -20°C, Army Group Centre resume
column3: In temperatures of -20°C, Army Group Centre resumes its offensive against Moscow. The German attack plan is to involve tank forces which are to drive with converging attacks from the north and south of the capital. General Guderian's 2nd Panzer Group begins advancing from Tula, while the 3rd and 4th Panzer Group will advance from the north toward the Moscow Canal. The infantry armies on the flanks are to make supporting attacks.

column1: The funeral of Czech Jan Opletal becomes the occas
column3: The funeral of Czech Jan Opletal becomes the occasion for a large student demonstration. In response, SS forces occupy all universities and 9 student leaders are executed

column1: Operation Crusader, the British Eighth Army's offe
column3: Operation Crusader, the British Eighth Army's offensive to relieve Tobruk begins. Rommel, who arrives back from Rome that day, is caught by surprise, allowing the British XXX Corps to advance 50-miles and capture the axis airfield 10 miles south of Sidi Rezegh. The Germans, believing that the British are about to encircle Bardia, send the Afrika Korps on a wild goose chase in that direction.

column1: 170 miles off the coast of western Australia, the
column3: 170 miles off the coast of western Australia, the Australian light cruiser Sydney discovers the German raider ship Kormoran. The Sydney approached to hail and was fired upon with both deck guns and torpedoes. The Kormoran has been responsible for sinking 11 ships during its tour. The Sydney returns fire and after a brief battle both ships sink. News of the battle comes from survivors from the Kormoran, no one survives from the Sydney.

column1: With artillery audible in the distance, Hitler dep
column3: With artillery audible in the distance, Hitler departs for Berlin from the Wolfschanze (Wolf's Lair), his headquarters near Rastenburg in East Prussia that he has occupied since the beginning of the war with the Soviet Union in June 1941. Although construction work continues on the headquarters, Hitler never returns.

column1: Battleship Kongo, the Imperial Japanese Navy's fir
column3: Battleship Kongo, the Imperial Japanese Navy's first superdreadnought class battle cruiser, was sunk in the Formosa Strait by three torpedoes from the U.S. submarine Sealion. It was the only battleship of the Imperial Japanese Navy to be sunk by a submarine and the last battleship ever sunk by a submarine.

column1: In the Atlantic, the German raider Atlantis is dis
column3: In the Atlantic, the German raider Atlantis is discovered and sunk while refueling a U-boat off the coast of West Africa, by the British cruiser Devonshire . In her cruise, the Atlantis had sunk 22 ships for a total of 145,700 tons.

column1: The Rebel siege of Chattanooga ends as Union force
column3: The Rebel siege of Chattanooga ends as Union forces under Grant defeat the siege army of Gen. Braxton Bragg. During the battle, one of the most dramatic moments of the war occurs. Yelling Chickamauga! Chickamauga! Union troops avenge their previous defeat at Chickamauga by storming up the face of Missionary Ridge without orders and sweep the Rebels from what had been thought to be an impregnable position. My God, come and see 'em run! a Union soldier cries.

column1: Two Luftwaffe officers, make the war's most audaci
column3: Two Luftwaffe officers, make the war's most audacious attempt to escape from a British POW camp. Lt. Heinz Schnabel and Oblt. Harry Wappler were prisoners in Camp No.15 near Penrith, Northumbria. Forging papers that identified them as Dutch officers serving in the RAF, they made their way to the RAF airfield at Kingstown near Carlisle and started the engine of a Miles Magister. Taking off, they soon realized they did not have the fuel to make it to Nazi-occupied Holland reluctantly they turned back, landing in a field about five miles north of Great Yarmouth. Recaptured, they were sent back to Camp No.15 again and sentenced to 28 days solitary confinement.

column1: Born Today: Karl F Benz (auto manufacturer),  Robe
column3: Born Today: Karl F Benz (auto manufacturer),  Robert Ripley (Believe it or Not), Joe DiMaggio (baseball player), Christina Applegate (actress)

column1: In the Bismarck Archipelago, during the night, 5 J
column3: In the Bismarck Archipelago, during the night, 5 Japanese destroyers, carrying troops to Buka in the Solomon Islands, are surprised by 5 American destroyers led by Captain Burke off Cape St George. Three Japanese ships are sunk.

column1: Japanese 1st Air Fleet sets sail for Pearl Harbor,
column3: Japanese 1st Air Fleet sets sail for Pearl Harbor, from its anchorage in the Kurile Islands. Commanded by Admiral Chuichi Nagumo, its consists of 6 aircraft carriers, 2 battleships, 3 cruisers, 9 destroyers and 8 oil tankers and has strict orders to observe strict radio silence.

column1: Born Today: Michele Puccini (composer),  Bruce Lee
column3: Born Today: Michele Puccini (composer),  Bruce Lee (karate star), Jimi Hendrix (rock guitarist)

column1: The Tobruk garrison links up the the New Zealand D
column3: The Tobruk garrison links up the the New Zealand Division of the Eighth Army at El Duda. Rommel forces, now under constant attack by the RAF is forced to turn his forces around in order to deal with this new development. Gondar, the last Italian held town in East Africa surrenders to British forces after a tough battle. The Italian commander, General Nasi surrenders 23,500 men, while the British suffer 500 casualties.

column1: The British 8th Army launches an offensive across
column3: The British 8th Army launches an offensive across the Sangro River in Italy. The assault begins with an air and artillery bombardment. A new bridgehead is established and the 8th Indian Division penetrates as far as Mozzogrogna. The defending German 65th Division is badly shaken by the offensive but German reserves have assembled behind it.

column1: In the Battle of Tassafaronga, American attempts t
column3: In the Battle of Tassafaronga, American attempts to stop the regular night supply run of the Tokyo Express under Admiral Tanaka again develops into a major battle. Tanaka has 8 destroyers and Admiral Wright has 5 heavy cruisers and 7 destroyers. Wright uses radar to find the Japanese force and fire the first salvo. However, the American attack is ineffective with only one hit on a Japanese destroyer which sinks later. The Japanese sink one cruiser and damage 3 very seriously. Despite this success, Admiral Tanaka is reprimanded for failing to deliver the supplies needed by the starving Japanese forces on the island.

column1: In the Philippines, Japanese attacks on Kilay Ridg
column3: In the Philippines, Japanese attacks on Kilay Ridge, on Leyte, continue. American forces successfully counterattack. At sea, the battleship USS Maryland and 2 destroyers are seriously damaged by Kamikaze attacks.

column1: In the Marshall Islands a task force commanded by
column3: In the Marshall Islands a task force commanded by Admiral Pownall and a task force commanded by Admiral Montgomery attack Kwajalein with a combined fleet of 6 carriers and nine cruisers. The Japanese lose 6 transports and 2 cruisers are damaged. A claimed 55 Japanese aircraft are shot down for the loss of 5 attacking American planes. The USS Yorktown conducts an air raid on Wotje.

column1: With the main forces of Army Group Centre just 19
column3: With the main forces of Army Group Centre just 19 miles from Moscow, Hitler abandons the offensive for winter and agrees to some local withdrawals to more defensive terrain. Zhukov launches a counter-offensive across the frozen upper Volga in the area of Kalinin, to the northwest of Moscow. He uses Konev's Kalinin Front for the purpose, but despite the severe cold and exhaustion of the German troops, his forces meet severe resistance, with only the 31st Army enjoying any success as it pushed towards Turginovo. Hungary and Romania both declare war on Britain.

column1: The final breakdown of deteriorating relations bet
column3: The final breakdown of deteriorating relations between the US and Japan. Roosevelt makes an appeal to the Japanese Emperor for peace. This direct approach violates Japanese cultural mores concerning the role of the Emperor and it goes unanswered. The US code breaking service has routinely intercepted and decoded all Japanese diplomatic messages and the most of the December 6th message is translated and sent to the President. It is clear from the message that war is imminent, but there are no specific details.

column1: At 6:15 Honolulu time, the first wave of Japanese
column3: At 6:15 Honolulu time, the first wave of Japanese aircraft take off from their carriers which are located about 200 miles north of Hawaii. At 7:50, 43 fighters, 51 dive-bombers, 70 torpedo-bombers and 50 ordinary bombers arrive over Hawaii. They launch attacks against the airfields at Wheeler, Kaneohe, Ewa and Hickham and against the American warships anchored at ‘Battleship Row’ in Pearl Harbor. Surprise was complete and within a few minutes 5 battleships and 2 light cruisers had been sunk and a large number of aircraft (180) destroyed on the ground. Within an hour, the second wave of Japanese strike aircraft (36 fighters, 80 dive-bombers, 54 bombers) had arrived over the target, sinking a further 3 destroyers and damaging another battleship. By 10:00 the attack was over

column1: Japanese aircraft bomb Singapore. The raid inflict
column3: Japanese aircraft bomb Singapore. The raid inflicts about 200 casualties, mostly civilians. Japanese troops land at Singora and Patani on the Kra peninsula in southern Thailand, which surrenders the same day. Japanese make landings at Kota Bharu on the north eastern coast of Malaya, although troops of the 8th Indian Brigade put up strong resistance against these Japanese landings. However, rumours that the Japanese had broken through the defenders, caused the RAF to evacuate Kota Bharu airfield and forced the 8th Indian Brigade to withdraw to the south after dark. Japanese troops launch an offensive against the new territories, a part of the British colony of Hong Kong. The Japanese overrun the US garrisons in Shanghai and Tientsin.

column1: Hitler lifts the ban on U-boats operating in US te
column3: Hitler lifts the ban on U-boats operating in US territorial waters two days before he declares war on the USA. This was to allow Dönitz to deploy 5 U-boats along the USA's eastern seaboard in order to be available for immediate action when the declaration of war was made.

column1: Born Today:  Georgi K Zhukov (Russian General),  R
column3: Born Today:  Georgi K Zhukov (Russian General),  Robert Koch (Nobel bacteriologist), Kamehameha V (Hawaiian King), Nikki Sixx (bassist)

column1: The Wake Island Garrison, with the support of the
column3: The Wake Island Garrison, with the support of the four remaining F4F Wildcats, repulsed the first Japanese landing attempt by the South Seas Force, which included the light cruisers Yubari, Tenryu, and Tatsuta

column1: Born Today: Gustave Flaubert (author), Frank Sinat
column3: Born Today: Gustave Flaubert (author), Frank Sinatra (singer), Jesse Owens (olympian), Jennifer Connelly (actress)

column1: Operation Winter Storm. German Field Marshal Manst
column3: Operation Winter Storm. German Field Marshal Manstein begins his attack to relieve the forces in around  Stalingrad. His forces are comprised of 13 divisions including 3 panzer units. The Soviet 51st Army is defending the area. Once the attack begins, the Soviets quickly move the 2nd Guards Army to take up positions on the Myshova River, however it takes several days for them to arrive and the 51st holds off the German attack alone.

column1: HMS Galatea was torpedoed and sunk by the German s
column3: HMS Galatea was torpedoed and sunk by the German submarine U-557 off Alexandria, Egypt with 269 killed. Some 100 survivors were picked up by the British destroyers HMS Griffin and HMS Hotspur. U-557 was sunk the next day in an accidental ramming by the Italian torpedo boat Orione with all hands lost.

column1: Frogmen of the Italian Navy penetrate the port of
column3: Frogmen of the Italian Navy penetrate the port of Alexandria in Egypt and cripple the British battleships HMS Valiant and Queen Elizabeth, along with a destroyer and a tanker. This means that Cunningham had lost all his battleships and could no longer muster a force strong enough to take on the Italian fleet.

column1: Born Today: Dr Samuel Mudd (Aided Lincoln's assass
column3: Born Today: Dr Samuel Mudd (Aided Lincoln's assassin), Kiefer Sutherland (actor), Peter Criss (Kiss drummer), Uri Geller (fork bender)

column1: Soviet forces halt a German army trying to relieve
column3: Soviet forces halt a German army trying to relieve the besieged city of Stalingrad.

column1: US Task Force 58, under Admiral Mitscher, conducts
column3: US Task Force 58, under Admiral Mitscher, conducts air raids on airfields on Kyushu. There are Japanese Kamikaze attacks by about 10 planes which hit Intrepid, Yorktown and Enterprise but fail to disable any of the aircraft carriers. Admiral Spruance, command the US 5th Fleet, is present for the operations.

column1: In the North Atlantic the British battleship Malay
column3: In the North Atlantic the British battleship Malaya is seriously damaged by a torpedo from U-106 when with a convoy in the Atlantic. The Malaya goes to New York for repairs -- the first major British warship to receive such help.

column1: French resistance member Pierre Georges commits th
column3: French resistance member Pierre Georges commits the first violent act of resistance against the Germans in Paris when he assassinates a German naval cadet in the Barches-Rochechouart Metro station. More than 150 Parisians would be shot by the Germans in reprisal.

column1: On the Eastern Front, German forces begin to withd
column3: On the Eastern Front, German forces begin to withdraw from Kharkov under pressure from Soviet forces. Field Marshal Manstein, commanding Army Group South, believes that holding out any longer would result in the encirclement and destruction of the defending German units.

column1: Born Today: George Washington Carver (Botanist), R
column3: Born Today: George Washington Carver (Botanist), Robert Duvall (actor),  Jean Dixon (tabloid psychic), Marilyn Manson (singer)

column1: British naval forces led by Brigadier General Bene
column3: British naval forces led by Brigadier General Benedict Arnold burned Richmond, VA. Arnold had previously been an American General until his plan to hand over the American fort at West Point, New York to the British for 20,000 sterling (about $1,000,000 today) was discovered. In a letter to George Washington he said, love to my country actuates my present conduct, however it may appear inconsistent to the world, who very seldom judge right of any man's actions.

column1: Born Today:  Constantine (last Byzantine Emperor),
column3: Born Today:  Constantine (last Byzantine Emperor), William Henry Harrison (US President), Joe Pesci (actor), Lennox Lewis (boxer)

column1: Born Today:  Chuck Yeager (US test pilot), ET Mana
column3: Born Today:  Chuck Yeager (US test pilot), ET Manager (Bucketeer Tool), Peter Tork (Monkees), Peter Gabriel (Rocker)

column1: Born Today: Bugsy Siegel (gangster),  Mario Andret
column3: Born Today: Bugsy Siegel (gangster),  Mario Andretti (racer), Bernadette Peters (actress)

column1: Second Battle of Kharkov – In the eastern Ukraine,
column3: Second Battle of Kharkov – In the eastern Ukraine, the Soviet Army initiates a major offensive. During the battle the Soviets will capture the city of Kharkov from the German Army, only to be encircled and destroyed

column1: Germany's conquest of France begins as the German
column3: Germany's conquest of France begins as the German army crosses the Meuse River. Churchill makes his blood, tears, toil and sweat speech to the House of Commons

column1: Rotterdam is bombed by the German Luftwaffe
column3: Rotterdam is bombed by the German Luftwaffe

column1: The Dambuster Raids by RAF 617 Squadron on German
column3: The Dambuster Raids by RAF 617 Squadron on German dams

column1: During the American Revolutionary War, the Contine
column3: During the American Revolutionary War, the Continental Congress bans trade with Canada

column1: SS troops burn down six villages in the Brkini hil
column3: SS troops burn down six villages in the Brkini hills in south western Slovenia

column1: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and U.S.
column3: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt set Monday, May 1, 1944 as the date for the cross-English Channel landing (D-Day would later be delayed over a month due to bad weather)

column1: The first prisoners arrive at a new concentration
column3: The first prisoners arrive at a new concentration camp at Auschwitz and 5 years later Alfred Rosenberg, the unofficial philosopher of the NSDAP and the person responsible for formulating the racial policies of the party, is arrested. He was tried at Nuremberg and found guilty of conspiracy to commit crimes against peace

column1: 950 miles off the coast of Brazil, the freighter S
column3: 950 miles off the coast of Brazil, the freighter SS Robin Moor becomes the first United States ship sunk by a German U-boat.

column1: The Pact of Steel was an Italian-German alliance i
column3: The Pact of Steel was an Italian-German alliance in the event of international threats, of immediate aid and military support in the event of war, and of collaboration in military and wartime production. Also, neither country would make peace without the agreement of the other.

column1: When the Royal Canadian Air Force's 115th Fighter
column3: When the Royal Canadian Air Force's 115th Fighter Squadron lands at Alaska's Annette Island, a US Customs officer refuses to let the pilots out of their planes until they pay duty on their arms and equipment. It takes a message from Secretary of State Cordell Hull granting the Canadians Distinguished Foreign Visitor status to end this idiocy.

column1: The Battle of Dunkirk lasted from around May 25 to
column3: The Battle of Dunkirk lasted from around May 25 to June 4, 1940. A large force of British and French soldiers were cut off in northern France by a German armoured advance to the Channel coast at Calais.

column1: In North Africa, Italian infantry launch holding a
column3: In North Africa, Italian infantry launch holding attacks on the British Gazala Line, which has been heavily fortified. British armor is being held in reserve, available for blocking any Axis outflanking moves. Rommel sends all his armor, both Italian and German, in a wide sweeping movement south of Bir Hacheim. The Italian Trieste Division engages the British 150th Brigade between Trigh Capuzzo and Trigh el Abd.

column1: Rommel has reinforced his troops on the Egyptian b
column3: Rommel has reinforced his troops on the Egyptian border and his two panzer regiments retake Halfaya Pass in a converging attack. The Germans begin work to fortify their new position, especially by digging in their 88mm guns.

column1: King Leopold of Belgium agrees to the surrender of
column3: King Leopold of Belgium agrees to the surrender of the Belgian army without consulting the other Allies or his government (now in Paris). The capitulation becomes effective at 1100 hours.

column1: About 400 American bombers attack German synthetic
column3: About 400 American bombers attack German synthetic fuel works and oil refineries at Polits and other locations causing major setbacks in aircraft fuel production.

column1: Four Japanese submarines arrive in Hawaii to inter
column3: Four Japanese submarines arrive in Hawaii to intercept the American task forces destined for Midway, but are too late to intercept the ships.

column1: The destroyer USS England  sinks the Japanese subm
column3: The destroyer USS England  sinks the Japanese submarine RO105, northwest of the island of New Ireland. This is the sixth successful attack on a submarine by this vessel in twelve days.

column1: Heinrich Himmler, commander of the German Schutzst
column3: Heinrich Himmler, commander of the German Schutzstaffel (SS), was scheduled to stand trial with other German leaders as a major war criminal at Nuremberg, but committed suicide by swallowing a potassium cyanide capsule before interrogation could begin. He had sent a personal application to General Eisenhower stating that he wished to apply for the position of Minister of Police in the post-war government of Germany, but Eisenhower refused to have anything to do with Himmler and he was subsequently declared a major war criminal.

column1: Born Today: Ferdinand III (Holy Roman Emperor),  P
column3: Born Today: Ferdinand III (Holy Roman Emperor),  Patrick Stewart (actor), Harrison Ford (actor), Cheech Marin (comedian)

column1: Near Crete, the cruiser Calcutta is sunk by German
column3: Near Crete, the cruiser Calcutta is sunk by German aircraft during the evacuation operations. Altogether 18,600 men are taken off, but casualties and prisoners in the battle for the island amount to another 15,000 from the land forces and 2000 from the navy. About 600 more men will escape later. The largest groups of prisoners are the 5000 men who are captured when the Germans take Sfakia and the garrison of Retimo who do not receive evacuation instructions. The British forces lose three cruisers and six destroyers. In addition two battleships, one carrier and numerous cruisers and destroyers have been damaged. The Germans admit casualties of 7000 from their force and Hitler decides that such large-scale airborne operations should not be repeated even though the result has been a brilliant success.

column1: In Italy the US 5th Army enters Rome in force and
column3: In Italy the US 5th Army enters Rome in force and continues to advance in pursuit of the retreating German forces. Traffic congestion on the limited road network hinders the advance, as does the German rearguards.

column1: The French line along the Somme between Amiens and
column3: The French line along the Somme between Amiens and the coast is broken by the attacks of 15th Panzer Corps after a vigorous struggle. Rommel's 7th Panzer Division makes the largest gains. Between Amiens and Peronne, Kleist's Panzer Group is still being held, but farther inland Guderian's divisions are seizing bridgeheads over the Aisne in preliminary attacks.

column1: The German battle cruisers Scharnhorst and Gneisen
column3: The German battle cruisers Scharnhorst and Gneisenau operate off the Norwegian coast. Their aim is to attack the various convoys carrying the evacuation from Norway to Britain. They sink three empty ships and then find the aircraft carrier Glorious and two destroyers. Despite a gallant defense by the destroyers there is no time for Glorious to escape or launch her aircraft, and although Scharnhorst is damaged all three British ships are sunk.

column1: In Occupied Czechoslovakia in reprisal for the ass
column3: In Occupied Czechoslovakia in reprisal for the assassination of Reinhard Heydrich (SS-Obergruppenführer, chief of the Reich Security Main Office), the German authorities level the village of Lidice and kill its population. More than 100 Czechs have already been executed in retribution for the assassination.

column1: The Germans are across the Seine west of Paris. El
column3: The Germans are across the Seine west of Paris. Elements of the French 10th Army are still fighting around St. Valery along with some British forces. Some of these units are evacuated from the town. East of Paris the German advance is also very rapid. Evacuations also begin at Le Havre. In the next three days 11,059 British and some French will be taken off, some to go to Cherbourg but the bulk is bound for Britain. East of Paris the German forces begin to gain ground south of the Aisne.

column1: Numerous German Luftwaffe raids, on targets in Eng
column3: Numerous German Luftwaffe raids, on targets in England, are carried out during the night. Leaflets are dropped over rural areas of East Anglia threatening starvation as a consequence of a German victory in the battle of the Atlantic.

column1: In Kwangsi province, China, 3 Chinese armies prepa
column3: In Kwangsi province, China, 3 Chinese armies prepare to launch an offensive to liberate the Hong Kong - Canton area. In Hunan province, the Chinese follow up the retreating Japanese as far as Paoching, which was the starting position of the Japanese spring offensive.

column1: On Okinawa, many of the Japanese naval infantry cu
column3: On Okinawa, many of the Japanese naval infantry cut off in the Oruku peninsula, reduced to a pocket of about 1000 square yards, begin to commit mass suicide to avoid surrender. The US 1st Marine Division captures the west end of Kunishi Ridge during a night attack. The US 96th Division attacks Japanese positions around Mount Yuza and Mount Yaeju.

column1: The Vichy government announces that more than 12,0
column3: The Vichy government announces that more than 12,000 Jews have been arrested and are being interned in concentration camps because of a Jewish plot to hinder Franco-German cooperation. The anti-Semitic laws in Vichy are being extended to include the expropriation of Jewish-owned businesses without compensation.

column1: The first raid by American B-29 Superfortress bomb
column3: The first raid by American B-29 Superfortress bombers is carried out over Japan. A total of 48 planes (of which 4 are lost) make an ineffective strike on the Yawata iron and steel works during the night from bases in China.

column1: American landing on Saipan (Operation Forager) beg
column3: American landing on Saipan (Operation Forager) began with a three hour air and naval bombardment. Elements of the US 5th Amphibious Corps come ashore with a force of 67,500 men, to the north and south of Afetna Point. The two beachheads fail to link up immediately, but the American forces do advance inland. The Japanese garrison consists of about 30,000 men.

column1: The German U-boat  U-205 sinks the cruiser HMS Her
column3: The German U-boat  U-205 sinks the cruiser HMS Hermione on its way back to Egypt, escorting the aborted convoy to Malta.

column1: Churchill broadcasts saying that the Battle of Fra
column3: Churchill broadcasts saying that the Battle of France is over and that the Battle of Britain is about to begin. His message is Let us so bear ourselves that, if the British Empire and Commonwealth last for a thousand years, men will still say, This was their finest hour.

column1: On Luzon, Philipines, elements of the US 37th Divi
column3: On Luzon, Philipines, elements of the US 37th Division, supported by an armored column, advance in the Caygayan valley, capturing Ilagan airfield and crossing the Ilagan River. On Mindanao, organized Japanese resistance comes to an end. Forces of the Japanese 35th Army have been cut off and have depended on roots and tree bark for food for some time now. Nonetheless, some small units of Japanese continue to resist.

column1: In the Philippine Sea in the early morning hours J
column3: In the Philippine Sea in the early morning hours Japanese reconnaissance finds US Task Force 58 while remaining undetected. The Japanese immediately launch 372 aircraft, in four waves, to strike the American fleet. Overall, the Japanese have about 550 planes (including those on Guam) while the Americans have roughly 950. Furthermore, US radar provides significant advance warning of the attack. There is enough time to launch an air raid on Guam before the Japanese can arrive over their target. American fighters begin intercepting the incoming Japanese planes while 50 miles away. Many of the attackers are shot down before reaching the American fleet

column1: Born Today: Edward the Black Prince (Prince of Wal
column3: Born Today: Edward the Black Prince (Prince of Wales),  Jack Dempsey (boxer), Al Molinaro (Al #1/Happy Days), Peter Weller & Nancy Allen (actors:Robocop)

column1: Rommel's assault on Tobruk begins. His plan is to
column3: Rommel's assault on Tobruk begins. His plan is to attack in the southeast with the German 15th Panzer, 21st Panzer Divisions and the Italian Ariete Division and drive through to the harbor. General Kesselring has sent all available bomber support from the Mediterranean. The attack begins with the bombing campaign in the morning and by early evening, German forces have reached the harbor.

column1: The garrison at Tobruk surrenders. 30,000 prisoner
column3: The garrison at Tobruk surrenders. 30,000 prisoners are taken by the Germans, but more importantly the huge storehouse of food and fuel fall into the German hands. More than 3,000,000 rations and 500,000 gallons of gasoline replenish the Afrika Korps meager supplies. Rommel requests and receives permission to continue the drive to Egypt over the objections of Kesselring who wishes to focus German forces on Malta with Operation Hercules.From Berlin: Hitler promotes General Rommel to Field Marshall in recognition of the successes of the Afrika Korps.

column1: Operation Barbarossa, the German attack on the Sov
column3: Operation Barbarossa, the German attack on the Soviet Union, begins. Despite the massive preparations spread over many months and the numerous indications Stalin receives from many sources, the Soviet forces are taken almost completely by surprise and lose very heavily in the first encounters. The Germans deploy over 3,000,000 men, 7100 guns, 3300 tanks, 625,000 horses and 2770 aircraft. The Soviet forces include 24,000 tanks and 8000 aircraft. On the first day of the attack almost everything goes the German way. The attack begins at 0300 hours with advances on the ground and simultaneous air strikes. The  Luftwaffe begins its operations very early in order to be over the Soviet bases exactly at zero hour. By noon the Soviet Air Force has lost around 1200 planes. The land battle is equally successful. The panzer spearhead Army Group North advances 40 miles during the day and Army Group Center captures most of the Bug River bridges intact.

column1: American forces of the US 7th Corps (part of 1st A
column3: American forces of the US 7th Corps (part of 1st Army) penetrate the outer defenses of Cherbourg. Elements of British 2nd Army also make gains. The British 5th Division captures St. Honorina, northwest of Caen.

column1: In Moscow, there is a victory parade at which capt
column3: In Moscow, there is a victory parade at which captured Nazi banners are ceremonially dragged across Red Square. The standard of the 1st SS Panzer Division Leibstandardt Adolf Hitler  is among the two hundred banners thrown on the ground before Lenin's tomb. Stalin and senior members of the government and Communist Party watched from the top of the tomb. Marshal Georgi Zhukov leads the parade, riding a white horse, the traditional Russian mount for a conquering hero. In a speech to the massive gathering, Zhukov said that the Red Army is the most powerful in the world, but the USSR must not become conceited or complacent.

column1: On Luzon, Philipines, Tuguegarao is captured by th
column3: On Luzon, Philipines, Tuguegarao is captured by the American forces in the Cagayan valley. Gattaran is retaken in the southward advance of the American paratroopers dropped at Aparri, after the Japanese had expelled the Filipino guerrillas. Penablanca is also captured. The surviving Japanese units on the island, about 50,000 troops, are now concentrated in the Sierra Madre area to the east of the Cagayan valley.

column1: Despite superior numbers of tanks and several fres
column3: Despite superior numbers of tanks and several fresh formations the British cannot halt the German advance into Egypt near Mersa Matruh, a seaport on the shore of the Mediterranean.

column1: On the Eastern Front forces of the Soviet 13th Arm
column3: On the Eastern Front forces of the Soviet 13th Army (Filatov), recently assigned to West Front, are struck by the attacks of German Panzer Group 3, advancing southward, and Panzer Group 2, striking northward. The panzer groups link up near Minsk, trapping another 3 Soviet rifle divisions in what is now the Bialystok-Nowogrodek pocket. There are about 20 Soviet divisions encircled.

column1: In the Cotentin Peninsula (part of the north-west
column3: In the Cotentin Peninsula (part of the north-west coast of France), American forces of US 1st Army prepare to eliminate German resistance in the direction of Cap de la Hague. The forces of British 2nd Army cross the Odon River on a 2 mile front near Mondrainville.

column1: Initial objectives of the Soviet summer offensive
column3: Initial objectives of the Soviet summer offensive are reached. The 1st Belorussian Front captures Bobruisk. The forces under Rokossovsky have destroyed over 350 armored vehicles, 2600 artillery pieces, killed 50,000 troops and captured 20,000 Germans in less than a week. The forces of 1st Belorussian now aim northwest toward Minsk with the aim of encircling German 4th Army, and the remnants of 9th Army, with forces of the 3rd Belorussian Front advancing southwest, while 2nd Belorussian pins down the German forces east of Minsk.

column1: In the Mariana Islands, the American 5th Amphibiou
column3: In the Mariana Islands, the American 5th Amphibious Corps has captured over half of Saipan. Fighting north of Mount Tipo Pale and Mount Tapotchau continues. Death Valley and Purple Heart Ridge are cleared.

column1: The outbound convoy PQ-17 to Murmansk has been dis
column3: The outbound convoy PQ-17 to Murmansk has been discovered by the German intelligence service B Dienst. Acting on this information, German U-boats  U-255 and  U-408 find the convoy. They are joined by 8 other U-boats and by July 6th the convoy had suffered the heaviest losses of any Russia-bound (PQ) convoy, with 25 vessels out of 36 lost to enemy action.

column1: The submarine USS Barb fires rockets on Kaihyo Isl
column3: The submarine USS Barb fires rockets on Kaihyo Island, off the east coast of Sakhalin Island. It is the first American underwater craft to fire rockets in shore bombardment. Meanwhile, Japanese sources report that only 200,000 people remain in Tokyo. All others have been evacuated to safer areas. The Japanese claim that some 5 million civilians have been killed or wounded by American fire-bombs.

column1: On the Eastern Front, Soviet forces of the 1st and
column3: On the Eastern Front, Soviet forces of the 1st and 3rd Belorussian Fronts complete the capture of Minsk. German forces of the 4th Army, which has been pinned by 2nd Belorussian Front, are now trapped east of the city. German casualties and equipment losses are severe. Most of the forces of German Army Group Center are in disarray.

column1: On Mindanao,Philippines the US 24th Division organ
column3: On Mindanao,Philippines the US 24th Division organizes an amphibious expeditionary force to liberate Sarangani Bay, in the south of the island, south of Davao. Filipino guerrilla forces assist in clearing out the Japanese pockets of resistance.

column1: On Borneo, reinforcements for troops of the Austra
column3: On Borneo, reinforcements for troops of the Australian 7th Division are landed near Penadjim Point in Balikpapan Bay. Australian forces have cleared most of the oil producing area in the immediate vicinity.

column1: At Mers-el-Kebir, Algeria the French battle cruise
column3: At Mers-el-Kebir, Algeria the French battle cruiser Dunkerque  is crippled by Swordfish torpedo-bombers from HMS Ark Royal.

column1: US Task Force 38 aircraft, 1022 in all, raid 70 ai
column3: US Task Force 38 aircraft, 1022 in all, raid 70 air bases in the Tokyo area, destroying 173 Japanese planes. Only light anti-aircraft fire is encountered. This is the first time that elements of the US 3rd Fleet have attacked Tokyo. Included in the task force carrying out the raids are the aircraft carriers Lexington, Essex, Independence  and San Jacinto, the battleships Indiana, Massachusetts, South Dakota and Iowa, the cruisers Chicago, San Juan, Springfield and Atlanta and 14 destroyers. Tokyo radio refers to the dark shadow of invasion in mention of the raid.

column1: In France German forces counterattack the US 1st A
column3: In France German forces counterattack the US 1st Army. The German Panzerlehr Division spearheads the assault against US 9th Division southwest of St. Jean de Daye. US forces hold. The British 2nd Army continues a slow advance. The 8th Corps captures Hill 112, southwest of Caen. Naval gunfire supports operations around the city.

column1: In Russia the pockets earlier surrounded by Army G
column3: In Russia the pockets earlier surrounded by Army Group Center have now all been cleared. At least 300,000 prisoners have been taken and more than 40 divisions have been eliminated from the Soviet Order of Battle. The panzer forces of Army Group Center are reorganized and have now crossed both the Dniepr and the Dvina, aiming to encircle Smolensk. Meanwhile, in the Ukraine, Zhitomir, less than 90 miles from Kiev, falls to forces of German Army Group South.

column1: In Berlin, British Field Marshal Montgomery, stand
column3: In Berlin, British Field Marshal Montgomery, standing beneath the Brandenburg Gate, awarded Soviet Marshal Zhukov with the Grand Cross of the Order of Bath. Acting as the representative of the King, Montgomery also awarded Marshal Rokossovsky with the KCB and Generals Sokolovsky and Malinin with the KBE. The British King's Company of the Grenadier Guards formed the guard of honor and tanks of the King's 8th Royal Irish Hussars were drawn up on either side. The ceremony was held in front of a banner proclaiming Glory to the Soviet forces who planted the flag of victory over Berlin.

column1: The German advance continues and the Luga River is
column3: The German advance continues and the Luga River is reached in the northern front. Meanwhile, Red Army artillery forces launch an experimental artillery battery of seven Katyusha launchers at Orsha in Belarus. The weapon was also known as a Stalin Organ (or Stalinorgel in German), so named by German troops due to the sound of its rockets, and its organ-like appearance (the missile tubes were arranged in parallel along its back, just as organ tubes are arranged). It was used on many platforms during World War II, mounted on trucks (including Studebaker US6s provided by the United States Lend Lease program), on tanks, and occasionally even on tracked artillery tractors. The attack is made on a German-held railhead causing substantial damage and panic.

column1: In Sicily, General Patton forms a provisional corp
column3: In Sicily, General Patton forms a provisional corps to advance on the west of the island while US 2nd Corps (Bradley) drives northward. In Catania the Axis forces retreat behind the Simeto River.

column1: At an important meeting Hitler, Goring, Bormann an
column3: At an important meeting Hitler, Goring, Bormann and Rosenberg decide on plans for the exploitation of the territory begin captured from the Soviets. Rosenberg is put in charge of a new ministry with the task of organizing the new lands for Germany's economic benefit and eliminating Jews and Communists.

column1: Montenegro (then part of Serbia) starts the first
column3: Montenegro (then part of Serbia) starts the first popular uprising in Europe against the Axis Powers

column1: Born Today: Napoleon Bonaparte (French Emporer),
column3: Born Today: Napoleon Bonaparte (French Emporer),  Julia Child (chef), Ben Affleck (actor), Adam Yauch (MCA/Beastie Boys)

column1: The first Anglo-American carrier air strike on the
column3: The first Anglo-American carrier air strike on the Tokyo area is conducted by the forces of the British Pacific Fleet , designated Task Force 37, and the US 3rd Fleet. During the night, the HMS King George V and 5 US battleships bombard Hitachi on Honshu. The Allied battleships fire some 2000 tons of shells on Hitachi in fifty minutes.

column1: Most of the town of St. Lo is occupied by elements
column3: Most of the town of St. Lo is occupied by elements of the US 19th Corps (part of US 1st Army). The British 2nd Army launches Operation Goodwood. A preparatory bombardment involves over 2200 aircraft including 1000 RAF heavy bombers dropping more than 7000 tons of bombs on the German defenses. British and Canadian forces push from east of the Orne River southward in the direction of the high ground beyond Caen. Initially, the Allied troops make good progress but no breakthrough is achieved.

column1: American forces in Sicily advance quickly to the n
column3: American forces in Sicily advance quickly to the north and west. On the east coast, the British continue to be held. Montgomery alters the weight of his offensive further inland toward Gerbini, Agira and Leonforte.

column1: Shortly after noon, a bomb explodes in the confere
column3: Shortly after noon, a bomb explodes in the conference room at Hitler's headquarters at Rastenburg, in East Prussia. The bomb was planted by Colonel Count von Stauffenberg - it was the third time he had carried the briefcase bomb into a meeting! The conspirators include General Beck, Carl Gordeler, Field Marshal Witzleben and General Halder. Most of them are either aristocrats or Roman Catholics. Many others know about the plot, including Rommel, Kluge and Canaris. After it becomes clear that Hitler has survived, the plot falls apart. Several of the leading participants, including Stauffenberg, are arrested and shot in Berlin by the end of the day - approximately 200 people were executed.

column1: Rommel sends a complete report to German Armed For
column3: Rommel sends a complete report to German Armed Forces High Command concerning his shortages. The British using Ultra intercept the information and decide to mount a major attack against him. Despite a 3 to 1 advantage in tanks, the British attack fails. There is mounting disillusionment from the soldiers at the way the armor is being utilized in these battles.

column1: US Task Force 92 bombards Paramushiro in the Kuril
column3: US Task Force 92 bombards Paramushiro in the Kurile Islands. During the night (July 22-23), 9 American destroyers penetrate Tokyo Bay under the cover of a storm and attack a Japanese convoy. Other Allied task forces are being resupplied in the largest resupply at sea operation of the war.

column1: On Guam, American marines on the northern beachhea
column3: On Guam, American marines on the northern beachhead reach Point Adelup. On the southern beachhead, the marines cross the neck of the Orote Peninsula, thereby cutting off the main Japanese airfield on the island.

column1: The battle cruiser Scharnhorst is hit five times b
column3: The battle cruiser Scharnhorst is hit five times by bombs from a force of 15 Halifax bombers while lying in the port of La Pallice. The repairs required will not be complete until 1942. Since Prinz Eugen has been hit earlier in the month and Gneisenau is under repair, this means that none of the German heavy ships in and around Brest are fit for operations in the near future.

column1: In the Marianna Islands, the heavy cruiser USS Ind
column3: In the Marianna Islands, the heavy cruiser USS Indianapolis  delivers the consignment of Uranium-235, needed to assemble the first operational atomic bomb, to the American base on Tinian.

column1: On the Eastern Front, the Soviet forces around Smo
column3: On the Eastern Front, the Soviet forces around Smolensk are cut off by the German pincer movement. The German 39th Panzer Corps (of Panzer Group 3) links up with 47th Panzer Corps (of Panzer Group 2) east of Smolensk and surround large portions of the Soviet 16th, 19th and 20th Armies. Meanwhile, in the north the Baltic port of Kallinn is attacked by the Germans.

column1: In the United States, an American B-25 bomber, los
column3: In the United States, an American B-25 bomber, lost in fog, collides with the Empire State Building in New York City. A total of 19 people are killed.

column1: In New Guinea, Kokada falls to the reinforced Japa
column3: In New Guinea, Kokada falls to the reinforced Japanese troops. Aid which might have helped the Australians stave off the Japanese advance turns back when the planes carrying supplies are told incorrectly that the airfield is in already Japanese hands.

column1: The US gunboat Tutiula is damaged by an attack by
column3: The US gunboat Tutiula is damaged by an attack by Japanese bombers in Chungking, China. Japan apologizes for the incident but it does not ease the strained relations between the US and Japan.

column1: In Britain, fighter output for July is found to be
column3: In Britain, fighter output for July is found to be 50 percent above the target figures. Since May 1st 1200 fighters have been produced. This is more than have been made in Germany and the RAF is therefore closing the numerical advantage of the Luftwaffe.

column1: The German bombardment of Sevastopol is renewed. G
column3: The German bombardment of Sevastopol is renewed. German artillery gathered for the effort is comprised of 1300 guns, including the two 60cm Karl mortars and the 80cm Dora rail gun. The attack is supported by 7th Air Corps.
